story:
On the 18th of September 2014, the people of Scotland face a choice of two futures. What kind of country do we want to live in?

Will it be a country which is fairer, more prosperous - a Scotland where all our people can reach their full potential?

Or will it still be a country ruled from Westminster; a country where we are held back by out-of-touch governments we didn't even vote for?

We can choose to remain with an unfair system which has created the fourth most unequal country in the developed world - a system which means we are forced to put up with damaging policies like the Bedroom Tax, nuclear weapons and austerity measures which hit ordinary working people the hardest.

Or we can choose to have the powers we need to do things differently - to create better quality jobs, increase opportunities for our young people and make things that bit easier for hard-pressed families across Scotland. We can harness our wealth, talent and natural resources to help everyone in Scotland prosper.

Voting Yes to put Scotland's future in Scotland's hands means we will be able to make our country the better place we all know it can be. With independence, we can take responsibility and choose a better future for ourselves and our children.

That's got to be the right choice for Scotland.


The Campaign

With less that 100 days to go, the streets are where it counts. Through canvassing, leafleting and the use of visual aids, we can win independence. Something many on both sides have overlooked but which is more important to us in the 'Yes' camp, is we want to 'normalise' the Yes position. Ie, in people's every day lives if they see pro Yes imagery it will gradually normalise with them and show that there are many others out there who feel the same. 

I believe that stickers are a fantastic way of getting the Yes message out. You may not think it, but hundreds of people will see these stickers every day.

Stickers are a brilliant way to spread the message, and the impact of thousands around Scotland will be fantastic, giving out the message that Scotland can be an Independent Nation.

We can't just rely on local campaign groups and the billboard ad's to do the job; as a collective we can make a massive impact to the quest to become our own country.

By contributing to this campaign, you can make a real difference to the success of "Yes. All it takes is a small donation via PayPal or Card and you have your very own pack of stickers...

What You Get

If our target is met, this will allow for the production of 25,000 Vote Yes stickers. This will also cover the cost of postage for a pack of stickers (£1 for a pack of 50, more for larger amounts). In order to make these stickers affordable for everyone, please find below prices and quantities:

£3 - A pack of 50 Vote Yes stickers delivered to your door.

£5 - A pack of 100 Vote Yes stickers delivered to your door.

£10 - A pack of 250 Vote Yes stickers delivered to your door.

£20 - A pack of 500 Vote Yes stickers delivered to your door.


With less than 100 days to go, we can really the Yes message out there and show people that Scotland supports an Independent Scotland.

This will not only be a good advert to Undecided/No's but a morale boost to fellow Yes voters, and help normalise the 'Yes' position on the streets.

So let's make it happen, we have 30 days to get 25000 Yes Stickers out into your the streets and advertise the message of Yes.


How You Can Help

Even if you can't financially contribute to the "Vote Yes Stickers" campaign, it doesn't mean you can't make a difference. Share us with your friends and family, via Yes Groups, Social Media sites and by using the IndieGogo Sharing tools... a share is just as good as a purchase!

Once again, thanks for reading my pitch and I hope you will be able to contribute to the success of  Vote Yes stickers.

Here's to a fantastic summer of Yes, and a win in September.

story:
Summary

The Silk Road invites the adventurer up a winding path through a bower of arches hung with the most protected, the most secret, the most highly valued textile in the world: Silk. From the Land of the Rising Sun to the Birthplace of Democracy, the arches will evoke ancient civilizations. Fabric is one of humankind's earliest inventions, and perhaps its most important.

Silk has a long and varied history - it was traded as currency in many parts of the world for centuries. It was worth more than its weight in gold. The secrets of sericulture (the cultivation of silk moths and the techniques for extracting, spinning, weaving, and dyeing silk) were guarded for centuries. With this project we hope to teach people to pause and take time to appreciate all that silk can do, and perhaps use the path as a guided meditation, allowing the silk to wipe away the worries of the outside world. Silk against the skin brings it alive, and can bring them more fully into the present.

As participants walk through the arches, silk will drape across them, caressing their face and bodies, awakening the tactile sense. Chimes or bells attached to the arches can help to focus a guided meditative journey.

Adventurers may want to pause to rest in the center of the path, on a raised platform, under crossed archways, to view the scenery on a soft carpet. This focal point (the platform representing the Himalayan plateau) can serve as a meeting place, a performance space, and a base camp for expeditions.


Who We Are

We are a diverse group of artists, makers and creative types who are bringing together our skills for this project. Although based in Seattle, we're coming from Washington to California to create this art. We are being led by the vision and creativity of Julia Trimarco who has been to Burning Man three times and helped build the Nowhere to Nowhere Monorail in 2010. She is a costume engineer, a tailor by trade, and for over 20 years she's made her living designing and building costumes in professional theatre. She first discovered the history of sericulture and the silk road while in graduate school in New York, while earning her MFA. 


Update:

We've just returned from debuting the Silk Road at Critical Northwest, a regional Burning Man festival that happens near Seattle every year. We presented three arches for a taste of the full road that will be at the Burn. Please view our Gallery for photos from this event. The art was extremely well received and the community appears eager to see the full installation.


What We Need and What You Get

We've been fortunate to have both the organizations of Burning Man and Ignition Northwest see the vision of this project and offer funding to back it. Therefore, our construction is well underway. As with most art, however, there are often unanticipated challenges that come up along the way. Some of our expenses that are still upcoming include:

* additional lumber, silk, lights and  building materials.

* fuel to transport the art to the events.

* administrative costs such as rental of the work space

Your contribution not only brings unique interactive art to thousands of community of participants, but allows you to keep a piece of that art to display your role as a patron. Please view our gallery for photos of the perks available.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Please consider sharing your interest in this project with friends. Either posting about it in social media or speaking about it directly all help us to find connections.

of the outside world. Silk against the skin brings it alive, and can bring them
more fully into the present.
As participants walk through the
arches, silk will drape across them, caressing their face and bodies, awakening
the tactile sense. Chimes or bells attached to the arches can help to focus a
guided meditative journey.
Adventurers may want to pause to
rest in the center of the path, on a raised platform, under crossed archways,
to view the scenery on a soft carpet. This focal point (the platform
representing the Himalayan plateau) can serve as a meeting place, a performance
space, and a base camp for expeditions.
Who We AreWe are a diverse group of artists, makers and creative types who are bringing together our skills for this project. Although based in Seattle, we're coming from Washington to California to create this art. We are being led by the vision and creativity of Julia Trimarco who has been to Burning Man three times and helped build the Nowhere to Nowhere Monorail
in 2010. She is a costume engineer, a tailor by trade, and for over 20 years she's made her living designing
and building costumes in professional theatre. She first discovered the history
of sericulture and the silk road while in graduate school in New York, while earning her MFA. Update:We've just returned from debuting the Silk Road at Critical Northwest, a regional Burning Man festival that happens near Seattle every year. We presented three arches for a taste of the full road that will be at the Burn. Please view our Gallery for photos from this event. The art was extremely well received and the community appears eager to see the full installation.What We Need and What You GetWe've been fortunate to have both the organizations of Burning Man and Ignition Northwest see the vision of this project and offer funding to back it. Therefore, our construction is well underway. As with most art, however, there are often unanticipated challenges that come up along the way. Some of our expenses that are still upcoming include: * additional lumber, silk, lights and  building materials.* fuel to transport the art to the events.* administrative costs such as rental of the work spaceYour contribution not only brings unique interactive art to thousands of community of participants, but allows you to keep a piece of that art to display your role as a patron. Please view our gallery for photos of the perks available.  Other Ways You Can Help  We know that not everyone can contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Please consider sharing your interest in this project with friends. Either posting about it in social media or speaking about it directly all help us to find connections.

story:
Support Lesli Patrock Makeup Artist & Time Obscured Photography showcasing their work!

Lesli Patrock Makeup Artist & Manda Rose of Time Obscured Photography are both participating in several showcases this year. We would love and appreciate your support!  Our goal is to network with others in the field, increase visibility of our work on the west coast, and open doors for new opportunities to grow and evolve as artists.


A contribution through our IndieGoGo is a way for our friends and supporters to assist us with the costs associated with these opportunities + get something awesome in return!


ABOUT LESLI PATROCK MAKEUP ARTISTRY

Lesli Patrock is a freelance makeup artist based out of Worcester/Boston Ma. I have been doing make up for over three years and specialize in a wide variety of make up styles. I don't think I have a favorite style of makeup but I tend to learn towards the crazy out of the box looks, although I do enjoy classic glamour looks as well! I feel as though I get a lot of my inspiration through color and the people I surround myself with. I hope to touch people's lives and to make them feel good about themselves with and without makeup. People always say, "Do what makes you happy!" and being a makeup artist definitely makes me happy. I hope to make a full time career out of it some day! I thank you so much for supporting our campaign any way you can and we look forward in showing you what we are capable of in our future Endeavors! Peace, love and lipstick!

ABOUT TIME OBSCURED PHOTOGRAPHY

Time Obscured Photography is the work of Manda Rose, an artist based in Worcester / Boston, MA. Through my photography I have been able to connect with unique humans and create something that I am passionate about and speaks to others. My images tend to explore the subtle qualities of human emotion and an idea of beauty that is not quite perfect- beautiful, yet quirky, often dark and a bit mysterious. I don’t simply aim to snap a picture of a person, but to take the subject to a level that is slightly more mystical. By spending time creating the initial look with each subject and then taking that raw image into the digital editing phase, I am able to meld the inspiration I get from my subject’s unique personality with my own personal expression. My goal is to network and work with other passionate people (makeup artists, stylists, designers and models), showcase my photos and evolve as an artist. Thanks for supporting my art and our campaign!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Some people can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help: Spread the word about our campaign via Facebook or the Indiegogo sharing tools, invite your friends to our upcoming showcase, "like" us on Facebook, and share our Facebook pages or personal websites on your wall / feed. Thank you!

story:
Joan of Art

Joan of Art are Suki and Thea Wilkins. We are illustrators, artists, art event organisers. We practise all different art mediums but they all benefit from our love of sketching. We love exploring the forests and rugged coastline around us in North Devon, as well as venturing up country and beyond. Helping us to deeply appreciate and remember our wanderings is our very own portable painting kit. 

Thea sketching in Blenheim Palace Gardens

 

The Sketching Tin

The tin will be available in a choice of 2 different designs

The tin itself measures in at 9.5cm x 6.2cm and is 2.2 cm deep (3.7 x 2.4 x 0.9 inches).

The base and sides of the tins will be either brass or copper coloured

 

The Tin contains:

 

3 x watercolour half pans

Primary Watercolours in Sketching Tin

These are highly pigmented watercolours giving a concentrated hit of colour. A magnet on the bottom of the pan secures it to the base of the tin or the palette lid, or anything else metal. We have selected colours that are useful as individual shades and also have great colour mixing capabilities when used in combination. There are four different ranges of colours to choose from, each with a different mood. Choose from:

Primary -

1. Cerulean Blue, 2. Permanent Rose, 3. Yellow. 

Strong, bold shades. Really versatile for mixing a wide range of useful colours.

Neutral - 

1. Indigo, 2. Van Dyke Brown, 3. French Grey. 

For painting in tones. Indigo is inky, Van Dyke Brown is rich and sepia-like. French Grey is fresh, calm and sophisticated.

Earthy - 

1. Indigo, 2. Rose Madder, 3. Yellow Ochre. 

Ideal for rugged landscapes. Robust and rugged colours. Evocative of wood, earth, gorse and clay.

Neon - 

1. Permanent Light Blue, 2. Hot Pink, 3. Lemon Yellow. 

Pure electric joy! Colours plucked from a candy coloured dream. These colours will light up your artwork like a fluorescent sign. Permanent Light Blue is like bubblegum. Hot Pink is like a tropical ginger flower at full strength and candy floss when diluted. Lemon Yellow is effervescent and zingy. When mixed with Permanent Light Blue it creates a delicious aqua.

Waterbrush

This brush fits in the tin in two separate parts - The brush with lid attached and the barrel with stopper. Water is stored in the barrel of the brush which is secured with a stopper. When you are ready to paint, the stopper can be stored in the base of the tin and the brush is screwed onto the barrel. Just squeeze the barrel gently when you want more water and let it flow through to clean the brush. A wide range of brush stroke thicknesses can be achieved. From broad washes down to fine details - this brush has it covered! 

2B Pencil 

We think 2B is the ideal pencil grade for versatile sketching.

2B Tonal Range

Eraser 

Great for removing mistakes as well as adding highlights by taking away areas of pencil.

Pencil Sharpener 

This sturdy sharpener will keep your pencil lines clean and your details accurate.

Palette Lid 

The lid of the Sketching Tin is coated white for easy mixing of colours and wipes clean easily.

Cotton Cuff

Make your water go further by cleaning your brush on your wrist cuff before you squeeze water through it. Our wrist cuffs will be embroidered with our logo in black thread. We keep ours stretched over our Sketching Tins to protect the tin and for easy carrying.

Embroidered Wrist Cuff

The Sketching Tin Manual

Complete with colour wheel, gradients to demonstrate the scope of the colours, tips and ideas for sketching subjects and techniques.

 

Why we are passionate about Sketching Tins

Both of us at Joan of Art are avid sketchers. We have enjoyed spending days together drawing around our local area since we first met. Our drawing days soon branched out to day trips further afield. And many of our happiest times have been spent travelling to new locations and drawing as much as we possibly can. From the very beginning of our drawing days, we have discussed and compared art materials, recommending techniques and tools to each other. These discussions and our sketching practise formed the basis of the development of the Sketching Tin.

Artists have been making their own homemade painting kits for a very long time. The practise of painting outdoors ('en plein air') became very popular in the mid 19th century with artists such as Claude Monet and J.M.W. Turner using Pochade boxes to capture the light on their subjects and in their landscapes. These were small painting kits typically made by adapting a cigar box. We were inspired by the historical use of painting kits but wanted ours to be more modern and even more compact than a Pochade box. We started by adapting vintage tins for our own use and were so impressed by how much refining our tool kit increased the effectiveness of our drawing that we continued to develop them, increasing the quality and functionality. Our trusty homemade companions have become the prototypes for the refined versions we hope to make. We have strived to discover all the highest quality elements for our tins and include all the best adaptions in one functional and durable kit.

We want everyone to be able to enjoy our favourite activity. We feel that too many people are so intimidated by the idea of being judged that they are too put off to try. But anyone can benefit from the positive effects of the process of making art. Whatever the aesthetic results are, they're not always relevant and they're certainly nobody else's business!

Sketching is good for stress relief, observational skills, memory retention, problem solving and just simply being happy. When you draw the world around you, you notice a whole new level of detail. Sketching helps you to see the world through new eyes.

Drawing is highly effective at enhancing connectivity between different parts of the brain. New research suggests it may even prevent age-related decline of cognitive functions. What more reason do you need to pick up a pencil or a paintbrush?

(see http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/07/08/how-ar... for more details)

When this project is completed, we will be creating online galleries on our website joacreations.com. We will showcase submissions from sketchers around the world. We will also share tips on getting the most from sketching, inspirational nuggets and suggestions on what to draw and how to draw it. With your help, we aim to foster a global, online sketching community. Please join us! 

 

Rewards

Square Postcards

We were inspired by Andy Warhol to create our postcards featuring four different art materials.

Pencil Postcard

Paintbrush Postcard

Ink Bottle Postcard

Dip Pen Postcard

 

Stickers

Our glossy vinyl stickers are strong, durable and plenty sticky.

Vinyl Stickers

 

Enamel Pins

Our enamel pins are made from die struck metal, then each design is coated in a different coloured finish. Finally, vibrant soft enamel is poured in. A coloured rubber clutch secures the pin and they are mounted on a backing card and packaged in a cellophane bag.

Black Metal Pencil Pin

Antique Gold Palette Pin​

Copper Paintbrush Pin​

Silver Ink Bottle Pin​

Silver Dip Pen Pin​

Credits

Music

The music in our video was written and performed by David Smale, percussion by Ryan.

David Smale: https://www.facebook.com/davidsmalemusic/

Art

All uncredited artwork in our video is by Joan of Art. Please contact us for details of artwork by Thea Wilkins, Suki Wilkins and Virginia Coryndon.

Steve Simpson: http://www.stevesimpson.com/ https://www.facebook.com/SteveSimpsonIllustration/

Hester Berry: http://www.hesterberry.co.uk/ https://www.facebook.com/Hester-Berry-225026604...

story:
Who is She?

Maia Joy started painting classes at the Iymanyi Belachew Art Academy when she was five. Her teacher started all of her young students out working on the floor painting on gessoed boards with acrylic paints. In the summer of 2011 Ms. Belachew began the Bob Ross Instructor Training in Florida and introduced her students to landscape and floral painting with oils on canvas. Maia quickly absorbed the lessons and began guiding the younger students.  She was recognized as a Top Ten Winner for Grade 3 in the Summer 2012 Celebrating Art Anthology sponsored by Blick Art Materials and in 2013 she completed a live painting, in front of an audience at a fundraiser for the Johnston YMCA that yielded a $1050 gift from a donor. Now, she is off to middle school having gained entrance to Northwest School of the Arts in Charlotte, NC.


What Does She Need?
Supplies - lots of them.  Maia is a prolific painter and keeping her in brushes, paint and canvas is a challenge. As her gift grows so does her catalog of paintings. They hang on the walls in our home as well as behind the couch, at the Bodega deli in NoDA and at Iymanyi Academy. $800 will get us through 10 months of the school year and provide her with what she will need for her schoolwork as well as her weekend painting classes.  Maia is an old soul with an entrepreneurial spirit so she would also like to use some of the funds to launch her own website and get some business cards and prints made so she can make her own money.  A laptop is on her wishlist too but she plans to earn what she needs to get that through sales of her paintings. 

So What Do You Get?
  • To Start - Gratitude. Your help provides a young artist more opportunities to grow into her gift and her mom an opportunity to take a breath and know that her daughter's needs in this area are covered.  Thank You!
  • High Quality Postcards, Prints and Original Paintings on Canvas 
     
Our Challenge

Your help will allow Maia to have what she needs as she embarks on this new stage of her artistic and educational life. Maia and her two sibilings are being raised by a single mom who is an artist herself. Laid off in early 2014, mom is re-inventing her life and career but doesn't want their current situation to impact what her children believe and know to be true about themselves and their gifts. 

Perhaps you can't contribute right now, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • So, ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about Maia's artwork and campaign.

  • If you know of a place she could exhibit please let us know.
Peace and Blessings!

story:
Short Summary

Fantasy and romance are handfasted together in this, my first

collection of artistic portraits. I have gathered the pieces of my

dreamscape to weave together a world of fairytale into singular

images where my subjects are transformed from mere humans into

fantastical creatures of beauty and magic.

Inspired by the work of Brian and Wendy Froud, the tales of the

Brother's Grimm, and the puppetry of Jim Henson in the Dark

Crystal and The Labyrinth, I lay awake nights stirring the cauldron

of inspiration and emerging with new ideas and stories.

The results are photographic collages designed to evoke feelings

of love and wonder in the viewer. To me these pieces feel simply

like coming home, even if my "Secret Garden" only exists in my

mind and on paper.

This campaign is a means to allow me to create prints of the first 20

images needed for my Gallery showing this November. I have managed to

fund enough for a handful of prints but I need a little bit more help to

get these images out to the world. I started by showing a few friends

what I had created and through their encouragement I am hoping to share

my art with everyone who needs a little magic in their lives. Anyone

contributing, even a few dollars helps me bring a little bit of that

magic to those who can appreciate it.


What We Need & What You Get

The money raised through this campaign allows me to purchase high

quality gallery wraps of the images and to ship and hang them. Each

gallery wrap costs approximately $100 to print and that does not include

the shipping or hanging fees. I have tried to raise the money myself by

selling smaller versions of the prints, but there is not enough

awareness of the images as the gallery show has not yet opened. This

opens up a unique opportunity for those who are helping out at this

early stage. Contributions to this campaign can earn you pre-released

limited edition prints, as well as other fun products, like postcards

and magnets. If I don't reach the goal, whatever money is raised will go

towards gallery wraps. If I make more than I am looking for it will go

towards advertising and celebrating the opening as well as submission

fees for additional galleries Nationwide.

The Impact

Growing up I had some challenges, I often escaped into my imagination. I

created beauty where there was only dismay and fear. Through the

creation of these invisible worlds I found my voice and my inner

strength. Not every image in my Garden is one of beauty, because even

roses have thorns, but in acknowledging the darker side of my mind I saw

where my light would best be served. Sharing this Garden with the world,

telling my own fairytales, I hope I show others that there is a Secret

Garden within them. A fantastical inner strength that given the right

nourishment can grow and bring light to others. Inspire them to grow. I

have already found interested galleries, there is already a call for my

work, I have taken it this far, I simply need the funds to make it a

reality. I have signed a contract with a gallery in Northampton MA. I

can create enough images to meet the minimum, but there is so much more

to share than that. So many more stories to tell.

Risks & Challenges

As I mentioned I can meet the minimum requirements of the gallery, but

the images will be smaller and have less of an impact. I will have 2

additional opportunities to show more than just what will hang in the

gallery on the day to day for the 2 months of the show. I want to show a

much of the images as possible. I am nothing if not determined. Once I

realized the value people saw in my work I decided I would make this

happen. I created my first image in February and less than 6 months

later have had interest from a number of gallery locations. I continue

to create one image a day. I continue to post these publicly on my

facebook gallery. I continue to gain interest and attention from others.

It is my intention to continue to put my work out there. I will also be

selling the limited edition prints online as soon as I complete my

gallery website. I further continue to participate in public events that

bring awareness to my art project, such as craft fairs and art

festivals.

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides donations you can help by "liking" and "sharing" my facebook

gallery: https://www.facebook.com/secretgardenart or by "sharing" your

favorite images and voting on them to help me decide which ones will end

up in the gallery. I also wouldn't be opposed to connections with other

galleries that may be interested in featuring my work. And of course by

sharing this Indiegogo campaign with the art lovers in your life.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Fantasy and romance are handfasted together in this, my first collection of artistic portraits. I have gathered the pieces of my dreamscape to weave together a world of fairytale into singular images where my subjects are transformed from mere humans into fantastical creatures of beauty and magic. 
Inspired by the work of Brian and Wendy Froud, the tales of the Brother's Grimm, and the puppetry of Jim Henson in the Dark Crystal and The Labyrinth, I lay awake nights stirring the cauldron of inspiration and emerging with new ideas and stories. 
The results are photographic collages designed to evoke feelings of love and wonder in the viewer. To me these pieces feel simply like coming home, even if my "Secret Garden" only exists in my mind and on paper.
This campaign is a means to allow me to create prints of the first 20 images needed for my Gallery showing this November. I have managed to fund enough for a handful of prints but I need a little bit more help to get these images out to the world. I started by showing a few friends what I had created and through their encouragement I am hoping to share my art with everyone who needs a little magic in their lives. Anyone contributing, even a few dollars helps me bring a little bit of that magic to those who can appreciate it. 

What We Need & What You Get 
The money raised through this campaign allows me to purchase high quality gallery wraps of the images and to ship and hang them. Each gallery wrap costs approximately $100 to print and that does not include the shipping or hanging fees. I have tried to raise the money myself by selling smaller versions of the prints, but there is not enough awareness of the images as the gallery show has not yet opened. This opens up a unique opportunity for those who are helping out at this early stage. Contributions to this campaign can earn you pre-released limited edition prints, as well as other fun products, like postcards and magnets. If I don't reach the goal, whatever money is raised will go towards gallery wraps. If I make more than I am looking for it will go towards advertising and celebrating the opening as well as submission fees for additional galleries Nationwide.
  The Impact Growing up I had some challenges, I often escaped into my imagination. I created beauty where there was only dismay and fear. Through the creation of these invisible worlds I found my voice and my inner strength. Not every image in my Garden is one of beauty, because even roses have thorns, but in acknowledging the darker side of my mind I saw where my light would best be served. Sharing this Garden with the world, telling my own fairytales, I hope I show others that there is a Secret Garden within them. A fantastical inner strength that given the right nourishment can grow and bring light to others. Inspire them to grow. I have already found interested galleries, there is already a call for my work, I have taken it this far, I simply need the funds to make it a reality. I have signed a contract with a gallery in Northampton MA. I can create enough images to meet the minimum, but there is so much more to share than that. So many more stories to tell.
  Risks & ChallengesAs I mentioned I can meet the minimum requirements of the gallery, but the images will be smaller and have less of an impact. I will have 2 additional opportunities to show more than just what will hang in the gallery on the day to day for the 2 months of the show. I want to show a much of the images as possible. I am nothing if not determined. Once I realized the value people saw in my work I decided I would make this happen. I created my first image in February and less than 6 months later have had interest from a number of gallery locations. I continue to create one image a day. I continue to post these publicly on my facebook gallery. I continue to gain interest and attention from others. It is my intention to continue to put my work out there. I will also be selling the limited edition prints online as soon as I complete my gallery website. I further continue to participate in public events that bring awareness to my art project, such as craft fairs and art festivals.
  Other Ways You Can HelpBesides donations you can help by "liking" and "sharing" my facebook gallery: https://www.facebook.com/secretgardenart or by "sharing" your favorite images and voting on them to help me decide which ones will end up in the gallery. I also wouldn't be opposed to connections with other galleries that may be interested in featuring my work. And of course by sharing this Indiegogo campaign with the art lovers in your life.

story:
(English follows Spanish text)

Nota: Sí quieren donar más de los 15USD y aún obtener su historia del libro por favor usar el método normal y después mandarme un correo con comprobante de donación y sus datos a ericka.bastias@gmail.com. ¡No hay límite para cuanto puedan dar!

NOTE: If you want to donate more than 15USD and still get one of the original stories from the book, use the normal method to donate and send me an email with the proof of donation and your information to ericka.bastias@gmail.com. There's no limit to how much you can give!

¡Hola! Sí andas rondando por esta página posiblemente ya sabes de que se trata esto, sin embargo déjame te doy bien los detalles: ¡Quiero imprimir un libro ilustrado! 

¿Sobre qué? 
Historias en Miniatura es un pequeño proyecto que comenzó hace ya más de 20 meses y del cual he ido aprendiendo mucho, conectando con personas en todo el mundo y compartiendo mis sentimientos/momentos/pensamientos que han sido compartidos y entendidos por miles de personas. 
Nunca me imaginé el potencial de estos pequeños garabatos y frases que se me ocurrían a deshoras pero ahora que esto ha empezado, no quiero parar. 

¿Por qué?
Sí me conocen sabrán que soy una soñadora, llena de planes, metas e ideas locas. Muchas de estas las he logrado gracias a una familia que me apoya, amigos que me animan y muchas oportunidades que se me han presentado en la vida. ¡Soy realmente bendecida! Así que por lo mismo es hora de devolver un poco de esto a través de uno de mis sueños más grandes: un libro.
Algo que siento que ha sido clave en mi vida ha sido la educación que pude obtener desde temprana edad; dos idiomas, actividades extracurriculares, deportes, etc, etc... ¡ARTE! Pero no todos los niños son así de afortunados y qué peor cosa que tanto talento, ideas brillantes, GENIOS en las ciencias y artes se queden sin aprovechar todo esto con lo que nacen, sin poder desarrollar sus talentos por falta de oportunidades. ¡Yo quiero ayudar en esto! Quiero apoyar a una igualdad no basada en regalos o en donaciones que se esfuman con el tiempo, si no en darles un poco de ayuda para desarrollar eso que los va a llevar lejos no sólo a ellos mismos, sino a todo un país.  

¿Y cómo?
Así que se me ocurrió esta idea: vuelvo a dibujar desde cero mis 37 ilustraciones favoritas, creo 5 ilustraciones exclusivas para este libro, edito por mi cuenta un libro con 42 ilustraciones (y con traducción al inglés porque ya es hora de que mis amigos de este lado del mundo entiendan esos mensajes a los que les han dado like por puro cariño), imprimo un libro, lo vendo... y así junto fondos para esta causa. 

¿Dónde va a llegar esto? 
La meta es recolectar los fondos y encontrar una ONG que trabaje en este campo de la educación para niños. No sólo quiero entregar el dinero sino también colaborar con ellos en toda forma posible incluyendo las historias. Creo que sí esto llega a ayudar aunque sea a 1 niño a seguir adelante, alcanzar sus sueños y entender que sus alas no deben ser cortadas, todo esto habrá valido la pena.

¡Sí tienen ideas sobre COMO apoyar esta causa, nombres de organizaciones no gubernamentales que necesiten ayuda, o decir "Hola, me gustan tus dibujitos" no duden en contactarme! 
Sí son una organización no gubernamental que quiera hablar sobre colaboraciones, talleres, murales, charlas, o cualquier forma en la que pueda ayudarles, no duden en contactarme.

historiasenminiatura Instagram link 
----------------------------------------------------------------
Hello! If you're on this page you possibly already know what this is all about, nevertheless let me give you the details: I want to publish a book!

About what?
"Historias en Miniatura" is a small project that started 29 months ago and from which I've been learning a lot, connecting with people around the world, and sharing my feelings/experiences/thoughts that have been shared and understood by thousands of persons. 
I never thought about the potential of all this doodling and quotes that popped into my mind at random moments, but now that all this has started: I don't want to stop. 

Why?
If you know me, you already know I'm a dreamer full of plans, goals and crazy ideas. I've accomplished many of these thanks to a family that supports me, friends that motivate me and opportunities that I have come across in life. I'm really blessed! For the same reason, I want to give back a little of this back through one of my big dreams: one book.
Something that I feel has been key in my life has been the quality education I was able to receive since a young age: two languages, extracurricular activities, sports, etc, etc... ART! But not all kids are as lucky and what can be worse than so much talent, brilliant ideas, GENIUSES in the sciences and arts to stay without exploiting all these with which they are born with due to lack of opportunities. I want to help in this!
I want to help this cause, not through a one-time gift or donation that will fade away with time, but giving them help and motivation to develop all these talents they have inside them and that will make them go further than they ever dreamed of.

How?
So I came up with this (hopefully) bright idea: I re-draw 37 illustrations from my page, create 5 new-exclusive ones or the purpose of the book, edit a book with 42 illustrations, print it, sell it and in this way get funds for this cause and a higher momentum to continue moving forward with a project. 

Where will all this lead to?
I'm not quite sure yet, but if I get to motivate at least 1 kid to follow his dreams, to work hard for what he wants and not to let his wings to be ripped off, all this will be worth it. 
I strongly believe kids are the future of this world and it hurts me to think that inequality chops the legs off of some of the best runners... Why we can and they can't? What made us so special since birth?

historiasenminiatura Instagram link

story:
Who are we?

We are located in the Center of Downtown Milford Delaware's Riverwalk.  We, Mispillion Art League are a volunteer led organization, whose mission is to provide community-wide access to a quality visual arts program.  We reach our goal through:

     •Education: The Mispillion Art League offers a wide variety of classes for persons of all ages and abilities.  Class lengths vary and are offered year round. 

     •Exhibits: The gallery has numerous exhibits showcasing the works of local artists throughout the year.  Exhibits typically are on display for 6-8 weeks.

     •Public Art:  Free monthly presentations are held on the third Thursday of each month January-October. These events bring the ART to everyone through demonstrations, slide shows, and personal narratives.

     •Community & Outreach: Mispillion Art League has served the community through its participation in the Downtown Milford Farmers’ Market, the annual spring Bug and Bud Festival, the annual fall Milford RiverWalk Festival, the and The Holiday Stroll. 

      The art league and its members contribute to the community brand, River Town, Home Town, Art Town, through the creation of major public art projects, including historic murals on the Salvation Army building, a children’s mural located in the public park along the RiverWalk and the Augusta boat project along the Mispillion Riverwalk.

In addition to ongoing members’ exhibits, the MAL has held collaborative exhibits with other community organizations, with students from the Milford School District, and to honor local artists.

The Mispillion Art League hosts outreach art classes for domestic violence victims, for children living in public housing neighborhoods, and individuals with disabilities.

In order to grow, we need your help. 

Milford, Delaware has long been blessed with many dedicated, talented and creative people interested in bringing the visual arts to the community. What was lacking was a non-profit visual arts organization to bring the visual arts and art education to the Greater Milford area. A steering committee of enthusiastic people met for several months in 2004. Finally, Mispillion Art League Inc. was founded and incorporated on June 15, 2004.  Now celebrating its 11th year, Mispillion Art League has opened a downtown gallery space, grown to over 300 members, gained an employee, and increased its education and outreach.  

The Volunteers of this organization share their talents and their time without any compensation.  

Currently, the art league offers a multitude of classes with medias like: Drawing, Painting, Collage, Pastel, and Photography.  Donations to this organization could increase the types of classes offered.  Some community interests are: Pottery, Stained Glass, Woodcarving, Mosaics, Printmaking and Computer Graphics. 

Keeping up with technology while saving money is truly a challenge. In order to stay on top of the evolving world, we need to update our computer, printer, and credit card processing devices. 

Our Perks include:

•Internet High-5 High FIVEs to you! Can you feel it? We appreciate your contribution, every little bit counts! $5 USD

•Thanks to YOU!- Just send us your Twitter or Facebook handle and we will be sure to thank and follow you for your generosity. $10 USD

•Kids Mural Card- Our "We Love Milford" mural was presented to the community on our 10th year celebration on June 14, 2014.  It was designed by one of our artists and founders, Sara Gallagher, from sketches submitted by children from Milford's Elementary Schools.  Funding Was provided by SeaWatch International.$25 USD

•Salvation Army Mural Card-  In Early 2008, the Mispillion Art League was asked to undertake the painting of six murals on the Salvation Army Building located on S.E. Front Street, based on Historic Photos.  A group of Mispillion Art League Artists and Volunteers from the community donated their time and talents working over four years to complete this project.  Local businesses provided financial support to cover costs and materials. The murals were unveiled on October 7, 2011. $35 USD

•6x6 Artwork and Free Class-  In June 2015, we held our first 6x6 fundraiser.  Local artists were asked to donate their talents to create stunning works of art on 6"x6" canvases. We still have a few fantastic pieces of artwork.  For $75 you can receive a free original piece of artwork and you may sign up to take a class of your choice in the new year. $75 USD

•Signed Print by Local Artist-  Hey! Thank you so much for your donation, we would like to give you one of our signed prints that have been donated by a Mispillion Art League Artist. $100 USD

•Original Artwork Do you like art?  We do! Just to show our appreciation for your donation, five of our Fabulous Mispillion Artists have donated an original piece of artwork, and you get one of their masterpieces!  $250 USD

•Sponsor an Arts Exhibit-  Each year we have about 7 Art Exhibits, would you like to sponsor one?  Your donation would help cover the cost of printing and refreshments for the exhibit, and we’ll be sure to put your name or logo on our print material.  $500 USD

•Sponsorship-  Thank you, Thank YOU. By donating 1,000 dollars your name or business logo can be placed on all of our electronic and print media for one year. It's a small way for us to show our audience how much your donation means to us. $1,000 USD

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not all individuals can contribute.  But that doesn't mean you can't help, Grocery receipts, volunteering your time and purchasing through "amazon smile" surely helps us out:

•REDNERS Receipts, Please save your Redner's Receipts and turn them in to the gallery, we receive 1% back as part of their "save-a-tape" program Click here for more info

•Amazon Smile: If you shop on Amazon, Click on the link below so that The Mispillion Art League receives 0.5% of your eligible purchases https://smile.amazon.com/ch/77-0637761

•Volunteering your time at the Mispillion Art League provides fun, relaxing, and welcoming ways to help out!

story:
Nicolas P. Macdonald ("Nickdemus") is a sustainble artist based in Eugene, Oregon, USA. Nicolas employs local artists whose talents combine to create the most highly detailed vision possible. Materials used are all sustainably harvested, re-used or recycled. His emphassis is on art that is tangible and fully interactive. Nicolas is a wordly man put simply. Being born in South Africa, he learned innumerable resourceful ways to make self sustaining projects in some of the harshest climates offered up by the Earth. 

I.  Nickdemus is currently bringing "Rocket" Science to the                        indigenous tribes and communities of Agato, Ecuador!

                 A "Rocket Stove" is:

* Made with recycled and raw materials

* A pizza oven, bread oven, surface stove and water purifier

*A radiant area heater that can heat in EXCESS of 1000 degrees!!!

* Eco-clean with no smoke or emissions

*Uses 1/8 the wood normally required!


"ROCKET" SCIENCE: AGATO  2012 is a 3 part, 3 month project bringing the Rocket Stove technologies to tribes, school children and indigenous artisans of Agato, Ecuador.  Only 1 in 50 people have access to heat and clean water in Agato.  They are left to cook and boil water on ground fires made of corncobs and eucalyptus wood.  These fires cause a lot of smoke and inefficiently use EIGHT times the wood of a Rocket Stove. In an area where the average monthly income is $240, the Rocket Stove can greatly enhance the quality of life for the greater community of Agato!

1. The Demonstration Model: Rocket Stove

    This portable Rocket Stove unit is being built on the farm of a local family.  Once completed, Nicolas & others will be able to travel with the stove to demonstrate & teach how to build the stove in Agato's many indigenous communities.  The main focus of the portable unit is to be able to take it far into the forests to share the Rocket Stove technology with those in very remote areas.

2. The Montessori School:  Rocket Stove

    30+ school children will benefit from this Rocket Stove!  This unique model features an earth bench running the length of the school.  The radiant heating surface will help provide the children with purified water and nutritious food.  It will also keep them warm this winter and for many more to come!!!

3. The Living Museum: Rocket Stove/Kiln

  The Living Museum is run by indigenous artisans who are preserving and showing the arts & cultures of the area's many tribes.  Showcasing the traditional fashion, weaving, fabrics and pottery of Agato's growing community of over 500 Indigenous Artisans, The Living Museum is a thriving cultural center serving the local population of 10,000 and representing Agato to the world!  The museum serves at least 30 local children as a school and many more as an after-school recreational area.  They also have free workshops for local adults who want to learn English.  A popular place for community gatherings, workshops and classes- The Living Museum is ready for a Rocket Stove!  

  Set in a 5 building decomissioned hydro-electric plant, The Living Museum will greatly benefit from a VERY large Rocket Stove that serves as a communal cooking surface, radiant area heater and kiln. This Rocket Stove is to be built in the communal courtyard/kitchen area and will heat 250sq. feet. The artisans are very excited about the role the Kiln will play in reviving indigenous pottery and ceramics!

 

II. RESOURCES

While Nickdemus sources re-used and recycled material, he still needs tools, some materials, and transportation to do the demonstrations.  As a one-man TRUE Do-It-Yourselfer, Nickdemus must spend 40-50 hours sourcing the necessary materials + another 40-50 hours actually building each Rocket Stove!
 
Some of the tools needed are: Grinders, hammers, rock chisel, hand saws, cement trowels, wheelbarrows & shovels.  The tools will be left in Agato so that the indigenous people may continue building Rocket Stoves.
 

III. YOUR PLEDGE @ WORK

Nickdemus has gotten to Ecuador and has already gotten started gathering materials and working on the first two projects.  To finish the projects Nickdemus is counting on YOU!  He has limited and infrequent access to phones, internet, etc. while working in these remote areas.  As such, The Ecoartbuilder Team is here to provide updates and answer any questions you may have to the best of our ability.  With your help, we look forward to doubling & even tripling our goal!  In truth, our base goal in no way comes close to covering the costs of labor for these projects.  These projects require a minimum of 240-270 labor hours to complete.  Nickdemus makes his livelihood with his eco art projects and has many projects empowering Global Citizens with EcoArt, Ecotecture and "Rocket" Science on the horizon.  

This campaign will assist Nickdemus in continuing to offer such incredible services to communities in need AT NO CHARGE to the community!!! We thank you in advance for your support of this incredible project!

 
You can make a pledge today for as little as $10 and provide five children in Agato with access to heat and clean drinking water! 60+ school children and 500+ indigenous artisans will be benefitting directly from these projects!  
 
The Ecoartbuilder Team will keep you informed every step of the way!  In the preposterously absurd, bizarro outcome in which the funding goal is not met, we may have to change the scope of the project.  We would say we promise to keep you informed if that happens.....but it wont, so, in truth, we don't have much to say about THAT because we ARE meeting our goal!
 

Thank you for sharing this project with your online networks, your facebook friends, your eco-friendly and green living networks, your church or spiritual center and absolutely EVERYONE you can think of who can support the success of this amazing project!!!  This is THE REAL DEAL.  No huge organization, no middle man- your pledges go DIRECTLY to assist the Indigenous Tribes of Agato, Ecuador!
story_txt:
Nicolas P. Macdonald ("Nickdemus") is a sustainble artist based in Eugene, Oregon, USA. Nicolas employs local artists whose talents combine to create the most highly detailed vision possible. Materials used are all sustainably harvested, re-used or recycled. His emphassis is on art that is tangible and fully interactive. Nicolas is a wordly man put simply. Being born in South Africa, he learned innumerable resourceful ways to make self sustaining projects in some of the harshest climates offered up by the Earth. 
I.  Nickdemus is currently bringing "Rocket" Science to the                        indigenous tribes and communities of Agato, Ecuador!
                 A "Rocket Stove" is:
* Made with recycled and raw materials
* A pizza oven, bread oven, surface stove and water purifier
*A radiant area heater that can heat in EXCESS of 1000 degrees!!!
* Eco-clean with no smoke or emissions
*Uses 1/8 the wood normally required!
"ROCKET" SCIENCE: AGATO  2012 is a 3 part, 3 month project bringing the Rocket Stove technologies to tribes, school children and indigenous artisans of Agato, Ecuador.  Only 1 in 50 people have access to heat and clean water in Agato.  They are left to cook and boil water on ground fires made of corncobs and eucalyptus wood.  These fires cause a lot of smoke and inefficiently use EIGHT times the wood of a Rocket Stove. In an area where the average monthly income is $240, the Rocket Stove can greatly enhance the quality of life for the greater community of Agato!
1. The Demonstration Model: Rocket Stove
    This portable Rocket Stove unit is being built on the farm of a local family.  Once completed, Nicolas & others will be able to travel with the stove to demonstrate & teach how to build the stove in Agato's many indigenous communities.  The main focus of the portable unit is to be able to take it far into the forests to share the Rocket Stove technology with those in very remote areas.
2. The Montessori School:  Rocket Stove
    30+ school children will benefit from this Rocket Stove!  This unique model features an earth bench running the length of the school.  The radiant heating surface will help provide the children with purified water and nutritious food.  It will also keep them warm this winter and for many more to come!!!
3. The Living Museum: Rocket Stove/Kiln
  The Living Museum is run by indigenous artisans who are preserving and showing the arts & cultures of the area's many tribes.  Showcasing the traditional fashion, weaving, fabrics and pottery of Agato's growing community of over 500 Indigenous Artisans, The Living Museum is a thriving cultural center serving the local population of 10,000 and representing Agato to the world!  The museum serves at least 30 local children as a school and many more as an after-school recreational area.  They also have free workshops for local adults who want to learn English.  A popular place for community gatherings, workshops and classes- The Living Museum is ready for a Rocket Stove!  
  Set in a 5 building decomissioned hydro-electric plant, The Living Museum will greatly benefit from a VERY large Rocket Stove that serves as a communal cooking surface, radiant area heater and kiln. This Rocket Stove is to be built in the communal courtyard/kitchen area and will heat 250sq. feet. The artisans are very excited about the role the Kiln will play in reviving indigenous pottery and ceramics!
 
II. RESOURCES
While Nickdemus sources re-used and recycled material, he still needs tools, some materials, and transportation to do the demonstrations.  As a one-man TRUE Do-It-Yourselfer, Nickdemus must spend 40-50 hours sourcing the necessary materials + another 40-50 hours actually building each Rocket Stove!
 
Some of the tools needed are: Grinders, hammers, rock chisel, hand saws, cement trowels, wheelbarrows & shovels.  The tools will be left in Agato so that the indigenous people may continue building Rocket Stoves.
 
III. YOUR PLEDGE @ WORK

Nickdemus has gotten to Ecuador and has already gotten started gathering materials and working on the first two projects.  To finish the projects Nickdemus is counting on YOU!  He has limited and infrequent access to phones, internet, etc. while working in these remote areas.  As such, The Ecoartbuilder Team is here to provide updates and answer any questions you may have to the best of our ability.  With your help, we look forward to doubling & even tripling our goal!  In truth, our base goal in no way comes close to covering the costs of labor for these projects.  These projects require a minimum of 240-270 labor hours to complete.  Nickdemus makes his livelihood with his eco art projects and has many projects empowering Global Citizens with EcoArt, Ecotecture and "Rocket" Science on the horizon.  
This campaign will assist Nickdemus in continuing to offer such incredible services to communities in need AT NO CHARGE to the community!!! We thank you in advance for your support of this incredible project!
 
You can make a pledge today for as little as $10 and provide five children in Agato with access to heat and clean drinking water! 60+ school children and 500+ indigenous artisans will be benefitting directly from these projects!  
 
The Ecoartbuilder Team will keep you informed every step of the way!  In the preposterously absurd, bizarro outcome in which the funding goal is not met, we may have to change the scope of the project.  We would say we promise to keep you informed if that happens.....but it wont, so, in truth, we don't have much to say about THAT because we ARE meeting our goal!
 
Thank you for sharing this project with your online networks, your facebook friends, your eco-friendly and green living networks, your church or spiritual center and absolutely EVERYONE you can think of who can support the success of this amazing project!!!  This is THE REAL DEAL.  No huge organization, no middle man- your pledges go DIRECTLY to assist the Indigenous Tribes of Agato, Ecuador!

story:
Top 2 Bottom, End 2 End

Mario Gonzalez Jr. needs your help in funding an international tour art project titled "Top 2 Bottom, End 2 End". Top 2 Bottom, End 2 End is a graffiti term that roughly translates into "Covering the whole surface." Mario's project will feature murals, art exhibitions and site specific installations in San Franciso, Korea, Italy, Switzerland, and Germany. His travels will take him from one end of the planet to the other culminating in his first major solo exhibition at the Zhou B Art Center (http://zbcenter.org/) in Chicago.

Mario Gonzalez Jr. (Zore) is an internationally recognized graffiti writer and has painted and showed his work throughout the UK, Netherlands, France, Germany, Spain, Brazil and Mexico. For the last decade, Zore has spent his time deconstructing wild style lettering and creating new forms of work. During his journey he will introduce his new form of urban modernism on an international scale. From home you will be able to study photos of his projects and read regular updates about his travels, collaborations with other artists and experiences. 

Upon his return Mario's anticipated Solo exhibition at the Zhou B Art Center in Chicago will be the culmination of the six-stop international tour and it will be curated by Sergio Gomez (http://www.sergiogomezonline.com/).

Your contributions to this funding campaign will make this happen!!  Please participate and be part of Zore’s tour around the world.

Project Itinerary

1st Stop
SAN FRANCISCO - May 7 to 15
Mural painting in the Mission District with Lilac Alley Mural Project.
www.missionart.com 

2nd Stop
KOREA - May 16 to June 7
T2BE2E, Two Person Exhibition
Artspace Mite-Ugro  
308-33, Daein-Dong, Dong-Gu, 
Gwangju 501-812, South Korea 
www.mite-ugro.org

3rd Stop
BERLIN- June 7- June 13 Site specific installation

4th Stop
SWITZERLAND - June 13 to June 18
Art Basel 
Site specific installation 

5th Stop
GERMANY - June 18 to July 2
Mario Gonzalez and two other artists will represent the US in the International Meeting of Styles. Sponsored by the US Embassy in Germany.
Wiesbaden

6th Stop
ITALY - July 2 to July 9
Art Energy and Future
International Group Exhibition celebrating Year of Sustainable Energy
Regional Museum of Natural Science 

7th Stop
CHICAGO - August 17 to September 14
Solo Exhibition
Zhou B Art Center
Opening Reception: August 17
Closing Reception: September 14 
www.zbcenter.org 

The contributions of this funding campaign will cover the costs of:

• Travel
• Supplies
• Housing
• Equipment 
• Promotion 

International Supporters 

• Zhou B Art Center, Chciago
• 33 Contemporary Gallery, Chicago
• International Meeting of Styles
• US Embassy in Germany
• Artspace Mite-Ugro

story:
The Center for Contemporary Art (CCA) in Bedminster, NJ is in the process of transforming its exhibition program to reflect a fresh, new direction!

Founded in 1970 by a  small group of artists, in 2010 we changed our name, signaling an organizational and programmatic shift designed to reach new audiences and to build vibrancy in these challenging times. We believe that we can best accomplish this by exhibiting the art of our time!

We have long been known for arts education and it will always be central to our mission, but the exhibition program is the most visible key to CCA's turn-around and transformation.

A new committee of museum curators, University professors, gallerists, professional artists, teachers and lecturers was formed to guide the development of a program designed to enrich the experience of students and members, and attract first-time visitors to our galleries and critical acclaim.

Unfortunately there is a real disconnect between the quality of the art work on the gallery walls and the condition of the exhibiton spaces themselves. This indiegogo project will raise funds to bring our facility to a new level by improving our galleries.

If full funding is not received, the project will be modified by replacing the old carpeting with new carpet instead of flooring in one or both galleries.

Please help us continue our transformation by supporting this project!

In addition to the satisfaction you will derive from helping a small non-profit arts organization take its programming to a new level, we also have some nice perks for you!

We need your help to spread the word about this project - please use the indiegogo "Share" feature!

Visit our website to learn more about The Center for Contemporary Art

story:
Airships were one of the first crafts built to bring humankind up into the clouds and now Airpusher’s Steampunk Airship is bringing the experience to Burning Man with a new twist.

Airpusher’s Steampunk Airship is a place for you to dance, laugh, stargaze, and get a breath of fresh air underneath the illuminated balloons of a classic airship. The Airpusher art car presents a new haven for DJs, musicians, and performance artists alike to showcase their talent on the playa with unique visual effects and a club grade sound system.

The Ship - Complete with 10,000 LEDs!

Airpusher is Burning Man made and a true labor of love for our group of Bay Area DJs, performers, and incredible support crew. Our unique car is being crafted by members of the community looking to heighten the boundaries of aural sensation and visual delight for everyone who sees us floating through the playa. Take flight with us and help us bring this amazing celebration of sound, light, and air to life!

From Dream To Reality

Meet Airpusher, a 40 foot long, visually stunning, double ballooned airship illuminated by more than 10,000 programmable LED lights. Passengers will dance and enjoy the view on the main platform with balloons suspended above and DJs rocking the airship from the platform below. The Airpusher is based on a CalTrans Engineers' truck with a steel frame that supports the main platform.  We’ll include a suspension system for aerialists to perform on either side of the ship. At night, a visual projection system will turn the desert floor into a performance space for aerialists, fire dancers, and anyone who wants to dance under the stars. In the heat of the day, the Airpusher brings relief with large fans providing air and a gentle misting system, like dancing through a cloud.

*Huge thank you to Jonathan Peedin for this first piece of concept art below - more to come for the perks! http://jonathanpeedin.com/

 

The Passenger Experience

2013 Cargo Culters will climb abord our massive machine and experience a second-level skyview like no other. You'll feel like you’re riding in the clouds on our replica of a steampunk airship!

Passengers and guests on the ground will be able to feel the musical experience produced by veteran DJs or live bands and the amazing sound system the car has on board. While the visual experience will be stunning at night, the Airpusher also provides entertainment and relief from the heat of the day by our industrial fans and misting system mounted on the back of the car.

Day or night, Airpusher provides an entertaining and unique experience for everyone on board or on the ground because we bring the entire party with us! We've partnered with Groove Hoops (professional hula hoop entertainers in New York) and Madamn Burnz (professional aerialists bsed in San Francisco) who will provide performers for as many of our shifts as they can. When we drop down to dance, we'll have dazzling entertainers to bring even more fun.

All burners are welcome to join us and party with Airpusher! You'll spot our 40 ft baloon soaring 20 ft above the playa from a mile off, so join us for a ride.

*Thanks in advance to Madamn Burnz http://www.rawartists.org/madamnburnz and Groove Hoops www.groovehoops.com for agreeing to join us on playa! And a giant thanks to Emily Martiny who created our amazing video! (Contact her at emilymartiny@gmail.com.)

Partner Camps

So, you already have a camp but no art car? Airpusher’s got you covered. We're welcoming other camps and performers to join us as we soar accross the playa.  As a special thank you for our largest donation, we’ll schedule a day and time to come to your camp, pick up 30 of your closest friends, and take you on a 4 hour playa tour complete with DJ and conductor. We’ll even program our lighting system so your camp’s name is illuminated on the ship!  Chose the "Partner Camp" perk to become one of Airpusher's partner camps.

What we have now:

We've got a great base to start from:

  • We have the truck - an ex CaltTrans Engineers' vehicle.  Its already been to the Playa, so we know it'll work 
  • We have the steel platform, an OSHA approved ladder to get to the second level, and sound system
  • We have an amazing Crew that includes Bay Area DJs, electrical engineers, mechanical and structural engineers, concept artists, camp organizers and a dedicated support crew. In total there'll be 50 of us on the Playa, helping make Airpusher's Steam Punk Airship happen
  • Outside of this campaign, in the last 30 days we've raised more than $7,500 from the Airpusher crew members alone

What we are asking for:

We have broken our needs into 3 phases.  We've already raised funds for Phase 1, this campaign is all about Phase 2:

  • Phase 1: $7,500 - Maintenance, Storage, and Legalities --> Raised from Crew

  • Phase 2: $9,500 -  Airship Transformation  --> This campaign
  • Blimp: $2000
  • Cloud around hull: $1500
  • Rent: $1000 (May 1 through Oct 1)
  • Generator renter for playa: $1000
  • Ladder: $500
  • DJ structure: $500
  • Lighting: $500
  • Ship Hull: $500
  • Arms (for aerialists): $500
  • Fans: $500
  • All the lIttle design details: $500
  • Gas: $150
  • Generator Rack: $100

  • Phase 3: $5,000 - Special Touches for an extra special airship --> If we exceed our goals

You can make this happen! 

Thanks for your support, we couldn't do it without you.

Blimp: $2000
Cloud around hull: $1500
Rent: $1000 (May 1 through Oct 1)
Generator renter for playa: $1000
Ladder: $500
DJ structure: $500

story:
What is Etiquette?

Etiquette had its first exhibition in 2010 and started functioning as an ongoing artistic platform in 2011. Since then, it has organised and curated exhibitions, readings, film screenings and workshops, each one dedicated to showcasing creative and critical work by established, emerging and aspiring women artists. Addressing gender as a subject of discourse, Etiquette uses art as a tool to create spaces within which critical and creative conversations can take place.

By mid-2013, Etiquette will have featured the works of over 70 artists, performers, writers, filmmakers, academics and curators as well as platformed a spectrum of gender issues and women’s concerns. It is also in the process of having its first anthology of women's writing published and its blog revamped; currenty the Etiquette blog features numerous articles as well as interviews the curators have conducted with international practitioners making feminist waves across the globe.

Why fund Etiquette?

By the end of 2013, we will be registering Etiquette as a non-for-profit arts group dedicated to showcasing creative and critical work by  women artists. We need your help to finance its exhibitions/screenings/gigs/readings/performances over the course of 2013, to formalise operations, streamline it processes and show our eventual backers that we have an engaged you with the work we have done so far. We believe that Etiquette fills a gap in discourse that is reflective of a glaring, gender-based power imbalance within the global artistic landscape. 


Who is Etiquette?

Etiquette is the lovechild of Tania De Rozario  and Zarina Muhammad.

  

What's on Etiquette's plate for 2013? 

Etiquette is platforming a number of events in 2013:

  • Mar 2013

What  Counts?
(A literary event to celebrate International Women’s Day, in collaboration ith AWARE singapore // One:East Asia)

Body Boundaries
(A preview of our upcoming anthology // The Arts House)

  • May 2013

The Vagina Monologues
(A V-Day event in collaboration with Sayoni // TBC)

  • Jun 2013 

Body Boundaries
(The launch of our first anthology)

  • Nov 2013

Etiquette III :Truth or Dare
Our bi-annual multidisciplinary showcase which will comprise:

  • A two week Visual Arts exhibition 
  • Literary Readings 
  • A two-day film festival
  • A musical showcase
  • Panel discussions
  • Workshops
  • Satellite events.


What You’ll Be Funding

Should you choose to support our campaign, you will be supporting not just the ideaologies that our collective stands by, but also the following very tangible costs: 

  • Marketing+Distribution costs of our upcoming anthology.
  • Subsequent Publications
  • Technical/setup fees for stagings, performances, exhibitions and lectures.
  • Print & Design of 2013 event collaterals (invites, posters, catalogues)
  • Updates+upkeep of the Etiquette website
  • Event receptions
  • Licensing/rating fees and for exhibitions, film screeenings and performances.
  • Commissioned articles and interviews for the Etiquette blog.
  • Photography/documentation fees.
  • Token Fees for artists, writers, filmmakers, curators and musicians participating in our end-of-year events.

 

What is Etiquette's track record like?

Events that we have platformed thus far include:
  • 2012

Sugar & Spice
(Literary Showcase @ The Pigeonhole, in association with AWARE Singapore)

Art & Agency: Sexual Autonomy in Art, Film & Literature
(Panel Discussion @ The Substation, in association with SlutWalk SG)

The Art of Censorship
(Free school curriculum developed for SchoolAsia.org)

  • 2011

Etiquette II:On Getting Down & Dirty
(Visual Arts Exhibition @ The Substation) 

Women Out Loud
(Literary Reading @ The Substation)

Etiquette Film
(Film Screenings @ The Substation)

A History of Modesty in Southeast Asia by Dr. Farish Noor
(Lecture @ The Substation)

POPIN Workshops @ The Night Festival
( Craft-based workhop @The Substation)

  • 2010

Etiquette:On Sitting Down & Shutting Up
(Visual Arts Exhibition @ The Substation)

Etiquette: An Introduction
(Presentation at the AWARE Centre in Singapore)

 

Who has Etiquette showcased?

By June 2013, artists, writers, filmmakers, curators and academics we have and/or are slated to showcase include the following individuals. Brackets denote the work that we have platformed and not the full extent of their professional practices:

Are you aligned with any organisations/NGOs?

Yes, we have been extremely lucky to have worked with and to have been supported by numerours organisations:

Supporting Venues & Organisations

  • The Substation
  • Objectifs School for Photography & Filmmaking
  • The Literary Centre
  • EROS Coaching
  • The Pigeonhole 
  • The Arts House @ Old Parliament

NGOs & Collectives we have worked with

  • Association of Women for Action and Research (AWARE)
  • POPIN
  • Sayoni
  • SchoolAsia.org
  • SlutWalk Singapore

 

By the way, what's up with the name Etiquette?

“Etiquette” as a practice, revolves largely around codes of conduct that enable an individual to negotiate a social space without conflict and on a larger scale, a community or society to carry on, as is. Our name is a sarcastic response to this tool that has been used for far too long to maintain status quos.

Gender, not synonymous with biological sex, is often perceived as natural. Assuming the roles of our designated gender unquestioningly is a form of etiquette that perpetuates existing power structures which discriminate against women in almost all spheres of personal and professional life.

For this reason, the rules of gendered etiquette need to change. We believe this starts with conversation. And we believe that art starts great conversation.

 

Where can I get more information? 

if you'd like to contact us to find out more about what we do, or if you'd like to be kept in the loop of this campaign, feel free to contact or follow us via one of the following channels: 

  • Web (awaiting update):www.etiquette.sg
  • Facebook:www.facebook.com/EtiquetteSG
  • Twitter: @EtiquetteSG
  • E-mail:ExhibitingEtiquette@gmail.com
story_txt:
What is Etiquette?
Etiquette had its first exhibition in 2010 and started functioning as an ongoing artistic platform in 2011. Since then, it has organised and curated exhibitions, readings, film screenings and workshops, each one dedicated to showcasing creative and critical work by established, emerging and aspiring women artists. Addressing gender as a subject of discourse, Etiquette uses art as a tool to create spaces within which critical and creative conversations can take place.
By mid-2013, Etiquette will have featured the works of over 70 artists, performers, writers, filmmakers, academics and curators as well as platformed a spectrum of gender issues and women’s concerns. It is also in the process of having its first anthology of women's writing published and its blog revamped; currenty the Etiquette blog features numerous articles as well as interviews the curators have conducted with international practitioners making feminist waves across the globe.
Why fund Etiquette?
By the end of 2013, we will be registering Etiquette as a non-for-profit arts group dedicated to showcasing creative and critical work by  women artists. We need your help to finance its exhibitions/screenings/gigs/readings/performances over the course of 2013, to formalise operations, streamline it processes and show our eventual backers that we have an engaged you with the work we have done so far. We believe that Etiquette fills a gap in discourse that is reflective of a glaring, gender-based power imbalance within the global artistic landscape. 
Who is Etiquette?
Etiquette is the lovechild of Tania De Rozario  and Zarina Muhammad.
  

What's on Etiquette's plate for 2013? 

Etiquette is platforming a number of events in 2013:

Mar 2013

What  Counts?(A literary event to celebrate International Women’s Day, in collaboration ith AWARE singapore // One:East Asia)
Body Boundaries(A preview of our upcoming anthology // The Arts House)

May 2013

The Vagina Monologues(A V-Day event in collaboration with Sayoni // TBC)


Jun 2013 


Body Boundaries(The launch of our first anthology)

Nov 2013

Etiquette III :Truth or DareOur bi-annual multidisciplinary showcase which will comprise:

A two week Visual Arts exhibition 
Literary Readings 
A two-day film festival
A musical showcase
Panel discussions
Workshops
Satellite events.

What You’ll Be Funding
Should you choose to support our campaign, you will be supporting not just the ideaologies that our collective stands by, but also the following very tangible costs: 

Marketing+Distribution costs of our upcoming anthology.
Subsequent Publications
Technical/setup fees for stagings, performances, exhibitions and lectures.
Print & Design of 2013 event collaterals (invites, posters, catalogues)
Updates+upkeep of the Etiquette website
Event receptions
Licensing/rating fees and for exhibitions, film screeenings and performances.
Commissioned articles and interviews for the Etiquette blog.
Photography/documentation fees.
Token Fees for artists, writers, filmmakers, curators and musicians participating in our end-of-year events.

 
What is Etiquette's track record like?
Events that we have platformed thus far include:

2012

 Sugar & Spice(Literary Showcase @ The Pigeonhole, in association with AWARE Singapore)
Art & Agency: Sexual Autonomy in Art, Film & Literature(Panel Discussion @ The Substation, in association with SlutWalk SG)
The Art of Censorship(Free school curriculum developed for SchoolAsia.org)

2011

 Etiquette II:On Getting Down & Dirty (Visual Arts Exhibition @ The Substation) 
Women Out Loud  (Literary Reading @ The Substation) Etiquette Film  (Film Screenings @ The Substation)A History of Modesty in Southeast Asia by Dr. Farish Noor (Lecture @ The Substation)
POPIN Workshops @ The Night Festival ( Craft-based workhop @The Substation)

2010

 Etiquette:On Sitting Down & Shutting Up (Visual Arts Exhibition @ The Substation)
Etiquette: An Introduction(Presentation at the AWARE Centre in Singapore)
