story:
A Photo's Worth a Thousand Memories

My name is Dennis Krupinski. I am a Husband, Father, Grandfather and Photographer. Until recently, I had a nearly 25 year career that ended earlier than expected with my diagnosis of Early-onset Alzheimer’s last year, before my 55th birthday. Unfortunately, I am not a stranger to this debilitating disease, having watched both my grandfather and my mother deteriorate and inevitably pass away from Alzheimer's. I have no illusions about my future unless better treatment or a cure is found. I need your Help.

Over the course of my 55 years, I’ve captured many of my most treasured memories on film. As a professional photographer, it is my nature to see the world through my lens and record the beauty and wonder I’ve experienced in my life. However, until my recent diagnosis of Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease. I did not realize how important my photography would become and how lucky I am to have actually documented my memories.

As a freelance photographer, it has always been a dream of mine to showcase my work in a gallery event. NOW, I have the opportunity; as well as the chance to build awareness of Alzheimer's disease and raise money for research to find a cure. I will be showcasing some of my most inspiring photography at the Early Memories Art Exhibition as a collaboration between the Alzheimer's Association Florida Gulf Coast Chapter and the Arts Ensemble International's Healing Arts program. Hopefully, with your financial support, my work will be on display for approximately one month beginning Nov. 7, 2013 in the Arts Ensemble gallery in Winter Haven, Fla.


My Campaign Snapshot

  • Help make my dream a reality! I am asking for contributions to pay for printing, matting and framing of a unique selection of 16-20 of my photographs to be on display at the Early Memories Art Show on Nov. 7, 2013.
  • As a perk to those who support my campaign, I'd be honored to share my love of photography with you by sending you a sampling of my photo cards, or a limited edition print from this special exhibition gallery, depending on your contribution level.
  • If I do not reach my fundraising goal, I will use the funds raised to showcase as many photographs as possible at the show. The importance of this gallery exhibition is beyond my own desire for a gallery showing. It is raising the awareness for those living with Alzheimer's and will help support the efforts of the Alzheimer's Association and the Arts Ensemble Education Foundation, so they can continue to do this important work in our community.


The Picture-Perfect Impact

After my diagnosis with Early-onset Alzheimer's, I realized that there is insufficient funding dedicated to finding a cure for a disease that currently affects more than 5.2 Million Americans.

Therefore, in addition to being an advocate for people living with Alzheimer's, I will also donate a portion of the funds raised from any sales of my photography during the show to these important nonprofit organizations - Alzheimer's Association and Arts Ensemble Education Foundation and Healing Arts Center.


Ways You Can Help

  • Donate! Any contribution is appreciated! $10, $20, $50, $100 - whatever you can do. I thank you for your support in advance. 
  • Spread the word! Share this on your Facebook page, Twitter, etc. or email your friends and family. Any support is greatly appreciated and the chances are that you have known, do know or will know one of 5.2 million Americans living with this disease every day, or the millions more who will face it in the future. 
  • Visit my dedicated photo gallery on my website to view and purchase an image from the Early Memories gallery. If you can make the event on Nov. 7, at Arts Ensemble International Gallery (Located in the CitraSource building) 1000 American Superior Bldg., Winter Haven, Fl. 33880 Please call 863-292-9210 to RSVP. If you cannot make the event you are welcome to view and purchase a photograph from this unique selection of some of my most memorable photos. Go to: http://www.4wildlife.net/Charities/A-Trip-Down-Memory-Lane I will continue to give a portion of the proceeds from photo purchases from this gallery to the nonprofit organizations mentioned above. Thank you for your support!

story:
What is The Red Museum?

The Red Museum is an old fruit-packing warehouse on the outskirts of Mansion Flats that has transformed into an epicenter of experimentation and raw arts culture in Sacramento. We provide affordable practice/studio space to local creatives and occasionally host highly-curated events that bring people of different ages, ethnicities, genders, economic backgrounds, and tastes together to experience new music, performance, food, and visual art for a reasonable entry price. We believe in the cultural value of providing exposure for emerging artists and we never want money to be a barrier between a good artist and a successful artist. We also want the public, no matter their demographic, to have access to this culture through our events.

Why do we need help?

Here’s the wrinkle in all that. First, earlier this summer, the City paid us a visit and gave us a list of upgrades to complete to help us become safer and code compliant. Secondly, we want to be able to publicize and promote our arts events to reach a wider audience. We have had a lot of support getting this started, but we need more help. That’s where you come in!

What are we offering?

We’re kicking this off with Red Ex: Vol 1, a mini festival on August 26th at The Red Museum. We wanted an event that felt very unified in vision but also represented the diversity of the current up-and-coming talent in our city. We didn’t book anything just to sell tickets – these are all people that we really believe are of high artistic merit and quality. We are also very dedicated to crossing over between often siloed art scenes – music, art, comedy, food – because we think that audiences appreciate being stimulated in different ways at one event. Sacramento has a warm community of artists and art supporters who are open to experiencing new things, making our city a really unique incubator for creativity.

How will we know if we succeed?

The success of this project will demonstrate that there is a path to helping art spaces survive in a changing and gentrifying city. By galvanizing support from city leadership, local businesses, and the community, we can ensure that the future of the arts is secure here in Sacramento. We’ve decided to make the Red Ex tickets the foundation of this campaign and have added other special perks from there. We appreciate any support and hope we will see you soon at The Red Museum!

We wanted an event that felt very unified in vision but also represented the diversity of the current up-and-coming talent in our city. We didn’t book anything just to sell tickets – these are all people that we really believe are of high artistic merit and quality. We are also very dedicated to crossing over between often siloed art scenes – music, art, comedy, food – because we think that audiences appreciate being stimulated in different ways at one event. Sacramento has a warm community of artists and art supporters who are open to experiencing new things, making our city a really unique incubator for creativity.
How will we know if we succeed?
The success of this project will demonstrate that there is a path to helping art spaces survive in a changing and gentrifying city. By galvanizing support from city leadership, local businesses, and the community, we can ensure that the future of the arts is secure here in Sacramento. We’ve decided to make the Red Ex tickets the foundation of this campaign and have added other special perks from there. We appreciate any support and hope we will see you soon at The Red Museum!

story:
Short Summary

 

My name is Samantha Cornwell-Crabtree, also known as Samantha CC. I'm a performance artist, filmmaker and curator from Brooklyn, NY. Although my background is in film, my art practice has been focused on performance in the last year or so. Through the New York performance community I've had the opportunity to connect with a number of other artists from the African diaspora who are doing beautiful, exciting work. Meeting all of these amazing people inspired me to start an ongoing curatorial project called The Great BE, or the great Black Expanse. I wanted to create community and exhibition opportunities amongst black artists, whether or not their work dealt directly with the black experience or not. The theme of the first show and zine was "survival" but this time we are focusing on "Abundance."

Speaking of abundance, in the time since our last show, it has become very clear that in order for the project to grow, and for artists to feel like The Great BE is a space that allows for the development of ambitious new work, I must find a way to compensate artists for their participation. Many of the artists who are, or have been involved in this project have to work several jobs to stay afloat, and in some cases have to miss a shift of paid work in order to participate in events such as this. Even performances that might seem ephemeral or effortless usually require a considerable period of rehearsal and conceptual development. Often artists have to rent space in order to have enough room to practice movement based work. With the state of the world being what it is, black artists are more likely to not have a parent or other family member who can loan them money to allow them  to focus on their art. A recent study found 80% of artists who have New York gallery representation are white. On a similar note, a 2015 study found that only 7% of people making a living off of their art in New York were of African descent. Those of us who become artists understand that we shouldn't be expecting a huge pay day, but artists shouldn't feel like they constantly have to choose between making work and surviving. Your contributions will help these artists feel like they can invest quality time and effort in their projects without it depleting their resources 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The primary goal of this campaign is to raise money to pay the artists. Although the artists will get a percentage of the money collected through ticket sales, we are also donating 10% of that to the National Association of Black Farmers, and since the venue's capacity is only 80, the amount we earn alone might not be enough to pay all the artists sufficiently.

On top of that, there are other expenses that we need to cover in order to make this event a memorable one. Since performance is so ephemeral, documentation is crucial. We need a budget in order to hire talented photographers and videographers to capture the events of the night. We also need budget to print items such as programs (complimentary) and posters (available for sale at the event and as a perk here.) At the last event I provided complimentary snacks for guests, and I'd like to have some money to do the same this time around.

We have a great collection of perks that come deep from the heart of the project. They include copies of our last zine, a chance to pre order the next zine, a video of the show, posters, exclusive performances and more!

In general, you get a chance to support the work of a group of very talented young artists who offer unique and beautiful visions of reality.

Our next show is July 13th 2017 at Outpost Artist Resources in Ridgewood, Queens and includes:

Anais Maviel

Tara-Jo Tashna

Kellian Delice

Jehoiakim

Elan Fraser

Karmenife X

Samantha CC

 

We truly appreciate your support. This project wouldn't be possible without it. If you can't back the project, please spread the word. This is the 2nd of hopefully many Great BE shows, so thank you for your support at this crucial time in our growth.

Yours in eternal gratitude,

Samantha CC

story:
Images of another Europe (1985-89)

Photographic exhibition at the Benaki Museum, Athens

September 26 - November 20, 2016

Photos by Costantinos Pittas

 

The purpose of this campaign is to pay the bills of the exhibition's production.

West Berlin, 1986

In the last few years before the fall of the Berlin Wall, in the end of the 80s, Costantinos Pittas roams all over the divided continent, from south to north and from Lisbon to Krakow,  in Eastern and Western Europe at the same time.  He points his camera to the faces of the scared and repressed people in the East, the faces of the lonely or the elderly in the West. Men and women who live on the verge of History deeply affected by it, all members of the big European family. His “naive” idea was to present the Europeans as an entity, as a big family, beyond borders and walls, in the space of a book. He stops shooting the day the Wall was down, on November  10, 1989, and he returns home with an impressive collection of images  which he buries in a box for a long time, not wanting to “make a career out of it”.

25 years later those photographs take revenge against their own creator, coming out into the light and taking him with them, making him share all these looks, the moments, the eternity of the streets, the loneliness, the kindness of strangers, the end of an era. Historical evidence and at the same time an artistic achievement by a photographer that neither reports  nor makes “art”. This unique work is presented for the first time in a large exhibition (160 photos) at the Benaki Museum in Athens, from September 26, 2016. 

Prague, Czechoslovakia, 1986

Waldeinsamkeit: my journey (book's preface)

I had “lost”, I had forgotten these photos for 25 years - later on I’ll explain why. When I found them again, a year ago, I was surprised with how old they looked, much older than their 25 years. Europe is changing today in a lightning fast pace and that’s why what I saw then, looks now like “another” Europe.

When I started all this in 1985, we had then a divided Europe, the Wall, two opposite camps, the Cold War, all that stuff. By that time I was a young person fascinated by Mitteleuropa, by its music, literature, history, everything. The division of Central Europe in particular –and consequently of whole Europe–, as well as the oppression in the East, overwhelmed me. And then I had this “idea” of traveling all over Europe, visiting European countries, Eastern and Western alike, photographing people living on both sides of the Wall, and presenting all these humans together in a book, beyond borders and barriers. A naïve and grandiose “plan”, like all youthful plans.

And that gave me the energy, the motivation to travel for the next five years all around Europe, from Lisbon to Warsaw, visiting 17 countries, always alone, with a small clunker running at 90km/h max, sleeping in it, spending the nights in highway parking lots or in the middle of nowhere, stopping in every city, walking for hours observing people in the streets, a big joy. And taking a few photos of them. And every winter I would return home to develop the films and work, waiting until springtime to take off again.

Paris, France, 1985

I visited Eastern Europe and I saw the misery in Romania, the oppression and fear in the eyes of people in East Germany and Czechoslovakia. And a somewhat milder life in Hungary and Poland. And at the same time I was visiting the West, and took pictures of western people in the exact same way as I did in the East. Western Europe wasn’t paradise for me, I was there to see the lonely, the elderly or the poor, most of the time. I soon realized that I wasn’t into “photojournalism”; I was unable to document reality. The only subjects I was really interested in were the human faces I could see in the streets, and the human condition, maybe.

And then, in 1989, the Wall collapsed, suddenly, without asking me whether I had completed the project or not... And my grandiose plan, a Europe with no walls, unified through photography, seemed more stupid than ever... So, I wondered what the heck I was doing all those years, what the point of all this was. The decompression was so abrupt. But I was in Berlin that cold November night and I lived the most exciting moments of my life, everybody there felt that way, we were living History, Freedom. Europe was changing before our eyes, walls were falling, it was magic. 

When all came to pass, I had to go back home, with no other plans and terribly disappointed. What I had in hand was of no value in my eyes. It wasn't “documentation”, photojournalism, it wasn't “art” either (“art photography” was something I couldn’t even stand). I felt that my work had no place anywhere. I had done something very personal and old-fashioned because that was me. And I didn't want to make a career on that, I had no motivation anymore. So, I buried the negatives away in a storage room and forgot them completely. And with them I buried that part of my life. I had family and a job to feed my family and I was happy with my new life, never missed the old days, never said anything and never showed the photos to anybody, not even my wife. I had totally forgotten my past and my photos, for 25 years.

Budapest, Hungary, 1986

And then, in March 2014, I found the old Minox in a drawer –all photos were shot with this little marvel. I remembered what I had done with it and found the negatives, in good condition. I scanned a few frames and uploaded them in Facebook. To my great surprise, they were a success with my friends there, and it was a big surprise for me because –I mean it– I’d never thought that anyone would be interested in my work. And then I uploaded more and more. I thought then that these human faces I saw in the streets of Europe in the 80s should not disappear with me, that they could live in a book. I made a first selection of 95 photos from the archive -et voilà! Here is the book, dedicated to my Facebook friends, to whom I owe everything."

Benaki Museum link about the event.

The detailed budget of the exhibition is here.

More information about me and my project is on my site. Thank you all for your time and support. See you at the exhibition!

story:
Hi! My name is Mara Jayne and I'm a young artist from Rhode Island. For the past few years I have been delicately balancing my college education and my job as a nursing assistant while selling my artwork at conventions and doing freelance illustration. Going to conventions, meeting people, selling my artwork, and learning how to be better at what I do brings meaning to my life.

Up until now the types of merchandise I've been able to supply at conventions has been limited to art prints, key chains, bookmarks, etc. In my spare time I've begun creating a series of illustrations aiming at expanding my artistic production, and am organizing something I have never attempted before: a book. 


The Video Game Pin-Up book is a publication comprised of 16 diverse and tantalizing pin-up style illustrations, each featuring a character from one of the most well-loved video game franchises of the decade. These art pieces are tasteful, sensual arrangements that celebrate the uniqueness of each individual character. These illustrations focus on highlighting all the things that make each subject uniquely sexy, including their sense of humor, physical features, and more.

The portability a book offers is unparalleled in other forms of artistic printing in terms of longevity, tangibility and quality. As an artist, I want to produce the best possible caliber of work in the most substantial format possible. Prints are great, but books give me the freedom to offer larger amounts of quality content to customers at economic rates.  

Revealed Characters:

Midna (Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess)

Booker Dewitt (Bioshock Infinite)

Jack/Subject Zero (Mass Effect 2 & 3)

Varric Tethras (Dragon Age 2)

Morrigan (Dragon Age: Origins)

Cloud Strife (Final Fantasy 7)

Lightning Ferron (Final Fantasy 13)

Connor Kenway (Assassin's Creed 3)

8 Secret characters exclusive to those who buy the book.


I’m hoping to raise $2000, with a cost breakdown below:

•  I’ve been quoted by the printer at a little under $350 to print 100 books.

•  $1000 should cover 300 books, 100 books for each convention I’m attending so far in 2014.

•  The other $1000 will cover travel expenses, including food, gas, hotel stay, train tickets, etc.

•  If there are any remaining funds, or if I exceed my goal, that money will go to printing addition artwork and purchasing table space at other conventions.

•  If I do not meet my goal, all the money I do make will still go to printing the art books.

If you can’t contribute financially, that doesn’t mean you can’t help. A big part of this campaign is letting people know what’s going on. You can help do that by:

•  Sharing the campaign video or link to this page on your facebook, twitter, tumblr, etc.

•  Like our facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Video-Game-Pin-Up-Book/585830361502009

•  Reblogging posts from my tumblr: http://gingerjuju.tumblr.com/

•  Telling a friend!

·  Give me an idea of how the book will look when it’s finished.

The book is being printed at the standard paper size of 8.5 x 11. All the pages will be full color, double sided, and printed on high quality gloss paper. The cover will also be full color and printed on a thicker gloss paper for durability. 

·  Do the pin ups contain nudity?

No. I’ve always thought that the primary role of a pin up is more to imply sexuality than anything else. It can be just over the top and a little risqué, but really it’s what the pin up leaves to the imagination that separates it from porn. While the illustrations I’ve created for this book are designed to be tantalizing and sexually implicit, everyone’s jiggly bits are comfortably covered up.

·  When will you be shipping books, prints, etc?

Immediately after the campaign is over and I’ve received the money from Indiegogo, I will be contacting the printers to begin manufacturing the books. Upon my approval of the proofs, it will take them 3 -4 days to print and ship the books to me. Depending on how many rewards I have to send out, coupled with actual shipping time. It may be a few weeks until the book is actually in your hands. But rest assured, it will get there!

Art prints and other rewards will be shipped out with the books.

·  What about digital rewards? When will those be sent out?

As soon as humanly possible. The moment I see a pledge claiming a digital reward, I will be emailing them to you.

·  What conventions are you attending this year?

MoCCA: April 4 – 5. New York, New York.

Connecticon: July 10 – 13. Hartford, Connecticut.

Heroescon:  June 20 – 22. Charlotte, North Carolina.

·  I’d like to talk to you.

If you have additional questions or concerns, would like to contribute to the project, or just wanna chat please feel free to contact me.

You can reach me via email: Offwiththeirhats@yahoo.com

Or message me on Tumblr: www.gingerjuju.tumblr.com

story:
Bedlam Lorenz Assembly (BLA) needs your
help to realize our first large-scale, ambitious
& independent exhibition in the premier, 8,000 sq ft. exhibition space in the center of Downtown Fort Lauderdale’s Arts District, FAT Village. 

BLA was founded in 2010 to bring contemporary art to Young At Art Museum and now we are committing to bring brand new works by global, national and local artists directly to you as an independent artist and curatorial collective. We were named “Best Curator of 2013” and received the “Best Exhibition of 2015” nomination by Broward, Palm Beach New Times.

Check out our gallery for images of our past exhibitions & projects.

With your generous support, BLA’s contemporary arts programming will be made possible, starting with Force / Effect, an immersive, site-specific exhibition by two of New York’s most exciting emerging artists, Sean Donovan & Richard Vivenzio.

Depending on the amount you donate, your name could be featured in a scrolling credit reel or on a comically over-sized sweepstakes check you can take home. You can also be personified within the installation or go home with an original artwork by BLA members and the artists featured in our upcoming exhibitions! Thanks in Advance is a production of BLA members Caroline Collette, Ben Morey, Tara Penick, Ali Shrago-Spechler and Zack Shrago Spechler and features a three-dimensional mural by Christopher Ian Macfarlane.

See the effect of your contributions on display and add to the fun at our opening reception during Fort Lauderdale’s premier arts fair:

Art Fallout | October 17th, 2015

521 NW 1st Ave Fort Lauderdale Fl. 33301

Assembly (BLA) needs yourhelp to realize our first large-scale, ambitious& independent
exhibition in the premier, 8,000 sq ft. exhibition space in the center of Downtown Fort Lauderdale’s Arts District, FAT Village. 


BLA was founded in 2010 to bring contemporary art to Young At Art Museum and now we are committing to bring brand new works by global, national and local artists directly to you as an independent artist and curatorial collective. We were named  “Best Curator of 2013” and received the “Best Exhibition of 2015” nomination by Broward, Palm Beach New Times. 
Check out our gallery for images of our past exhibitions & projects.

With your generous support, BLA’s contemporary arts programming will be made possible, starting with Force / Effect, an immersive, site-specific exhibition by two of New York’s most exciting emerging artists, Sean Donovan & Richard Vivenzio.


Depending on the amount you donate, your name could be featured in a scrolling credit reel or on a comically over-sized sweepstakes check you can take home. You can also be personified within the installation or go home with an original artwork by BLA members and the artists featured in our upcoming exhibitions! Thanks in Advance is a production of BLA members Caroline Collette, Ben Morey, Tara Penick, Ali Shrago-Spechler and Zack Shrago Spechler and features a three-dimensional mural by Christopher Ian Macfarlane.
See the effect of your contributions on display and add to the fun at our opening reception during Fort Lauderdale’s premier arts fair:
Art Fallout | October 17th, 2015
521 NW 1st Ave Fort Lauderdale Fl. 33301

story:
HELLO!

Hello, and thank you for visiting our page! We really appreciate your interest, and we hope that you are able to support us in our mission to create an amazing graduate exhibition!

YOU ARE HERE

YOU ARE HERE is a group of final year BA (Hons) Fine Art for Design students. We are from Batley School of Art, part of Kirklees College, holding our degree show at the school, and at Free Range London in July of 2014. 

We are a small group of people who live and breath art and design, across a plethora of mediums including:

Drawing
Painting
Photography
Film
Animation
Illustration
Costume
Sculpture to name a few!

Every year, our course has the option to showcase our work at Free Range London. We pay for most of it ourselves, and this year, we want to top every other year and make it extra special. We want to be able to produce a unique invitation, and an exhibition catalog that people will remember, keep and treasure. 

We ask for your kind support and donations, in order to create an exhibition catalog, something our course has never done due to funding.

With your help, we will create an degree show at Free Range London, that will showcase our talent, and help us create our own identity in the world, after graduating. 

We appreciate all your help. No donation is too small. If you cannot afford to donate, you can still support us by sharing our page with your friends and family. 

WHAT DO YOU GET OUT OF THIS?

We need to raise at least £500 for the printing of invitations and exhibition catalogues. These catalogues will tell people about our exhibition, our artwork, and us as people. 

You can support us by donating as little as £1. from as little as £5, you can receive a little gift from us to thank you for your support. For your kind donations, you could receive an invitation to the private view of our exhibition at Free Range in London, a poster/print, and a credit in the exhibition catalogue.


Thank you for taking the time to support us. Please donate, share our page, and we look forward to seeing you at our exhibition!

story:
I am having two group exhibitions in Europe opening within a week of each other in November 2015. The first - entitled 'Architectures' - is on 12 November at the prestigious Collection de l'Art Brut in Lausanne, Switzerland. On that date I am invited to attend a press conference at 11AM, and a special dinner for the artists in the evening. The second is the private view of 'Highlights of the Henry Boxer Collection' exhibit, on 18 November at Orleans House Gallery in Richmond, Surrey, UK. I feel I ought to attend, as they are so close in time, and I will have works at both. I fly Halifax-London-Geneva on 10-11 Nov., then Geneva-London on 13 Nov., and London-St. John's-Halifax on 19 Nov. I will find my own accommodation using airbnb.com . I feel it is necessary to attend these important gallery openings, even though I am not naturally a schmoozer, in order to further my career as an Outsider artist and creator of art brut.

I require funds for travel insurance, 8 nights accommodation and meals, and train/tube fare.

story:
Revival Gallery is an art space in need of funding in order to continue producing quality events that breath life into the creative community in the Fitchburg area. 

     Run by a cooperative of resident artists, our humble downtown storefront serves as a studio, gallery, and venue. During the past year alone, we have brought eleven free exhibits to the scene, featuring over fifty artists and musicians from all across New England-- most of them from our twin city region. Recognizing and celebrating the local talent that this area has to offer is an important part of our core mission-- which is simply to promote visual arts as an accessible form of entertainment on Main Street. But we have also attracted artists and visitors alike from as far as New York City. The outpouring of interest in this cause has enriched our vision of Revival Gallery as a catalyst towards greater cultural wealth at a grassroots level. In reflecting on all our interactions with the inspiring people we've met since beginning this journey last Spring, including artists, musicians, business owners, community leaders, and the regular inhabitants of Fitchburg that create its' distinctive vibe, we know that Revival Gallery is an important part of the change. 

     However, we have reached an obstacle. In order to meet current regulations, we must perform several costly updates and renovations to our gallery space. We have projected this cost to be upwards of one thousand dollars. After considering all the personal and financial sacrifices the resident members of the gallery have already made, this figure simply cannot be met on top of rent and utilities. 

     We are asking for help. If you've ever come to one of our shows, enjoyed some of the art that's been produced here, attended a partner event that we painted murals for, known someone that had an opportunity to showcase their hard work, or even driven by and enjoyed the look of a full window display on an otherwise dusty row of empty shops, please consider donating. You get awesome presents in return for your generous support, so it's a win-win situation.

     Each of the perks offered in exchange for a donation represent a specialty of one or more of our resident artists. Among the deals are original artworks and prints to add to your personal collection, sticker packs so you can wear your support on an accessory of your choice, private art instruction, hoop dance lessons, and a personalized photo shoot with our photographer. Browse the other perks for more deals that may strike your fancy.

     So by now, you should have a good idea about what the Revival Gallery is, what we are trying to do for the revitalization of the city of Fitchburg, and ways that you can monetarily donate to our cause. What you may not realize is that even if you cannot afford to put in a donation, you can still help! You could share this page on your favorite social media site. Tell people about what we are trying to accomplish, and what to expect out of our group. You can also share any (or all) of our campaign videos to your friends, so they can see us in action and get to better know the group they are investing in. Come to any of our events, see how we run the business, how close our community ties are, and how motivated we are to become a wonderful addition to downtown Fitchburg. We love this town, and would love to see it restored to its former cultural glory. And the Revival Gallery is a step in the right direction towards this goal. Thank you so much for taking the time to read about us, I hope we have convinced you that we are a cause worth supporting!

story:
What's the story morning glory?


Playwright Cat Crowley and composer Nate Weida have teamed up to create a new gender-defying QUEER 50s MUSICAL! Together with director Annie Tippe, they will be presenting the brilliantly bodacious Blue Plate Special at Ars Nova on June 7th at 7pm!

But they can't do it without your help!


Dreamy and haunting as any doo-wop song. Vibrant and entertaining as any juke-box jam. And guaranteed more queer than that summer camp production of Grease you were in where half the T-Birds were played by girls. Blue Plate Special is a musical fracturing of all the fun and classic ‘50s tropes you know and love, featuring an all-queer cast of characters.

There’s Zebra Bravo and the Zebra Bravo gang; wanna-be greasers bent on being tough. Cherry-Red, a poodle-skirt princess who must also contend with being a werewolf. Glendanette, the haggard diner waitress who longs to drink from the Soda Fountain of Youth. And the greasy-spoon Fry-Cook Joe, whose dreams of culinary virtuosity verge on mad-scientist shenanigans when they bring to life— bum-bum-bum— the Blue Plate Special; a comestible companion who grapples with deeper philosophical questions of identity.

Whether at the diner, the drive-in, or the Big Dance, watch as these story-lines go rama-lamma-lamming into each other in the most delightful and unexpected ways! Blue Plate Special promises to be a strange, humorous— and let’s not forget musical!— celebration of gender and sexuality, as well as a meditative sock-hop on the two most central themes to every major ‘50s narrative: youth and love.


Where your dime goes...

  • We've got a big cast and we believe they should get paid! The majority of these funds will be going towards paying the nine LGBTQ+ identified performers and four musicians involved.
  • Our design team also needs proper funding. We've gotta set the scene for a diner, a marsh, a drive-in, a drag race, and the Big Dance! And did we mention we've got a cast of nine performers and four musicians who'd rather not be standing up there naked?
  • Rehearsal space doesn't come cheap, but we've gotta rehearse somewhere big enough to fit our cast of NINE performers and FOUR musicians. We need designated funds to rent space throughout the month of May and the first week of June.


The dealio, daddio!

Blue Plate Special can't be a success without the help of outside financial support. We've estimated a number and are asking you, our dearest friends and family, to help us meet our goal!

If you're short on scratch please share our campaign via email and social media!

If you can't get enough of supporting the show go ahead and share our Facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/797643627034174/

And BUY TICKETS here.

story:
Who are we, And What are we doing?-

We are a group of Fine Artists, studying in our final year at The University For The Creative Arts, Farnham and we are raising money for our Degree show, in the Copeland Gallery, Peckham, London.

What We Need & What You Get For Donating!-

  • We are looking to raise £1500, This amount will help us cover gallery fees, promotional fees, and Van Hire fees. Every little helps and every donation will lead us to our goal!
  • We want you to get excited about our exhibition, So if you donate to our project, we will allow you to have a print of one of the selected artists works! You donate- You get a unique piece of art!

The Impact Of Our Project!-

  • This project will allow us, as final year students, to establish ourselves as artists, and to get our work seen! 
  • The group, as well as this exhibition has held successful and Intriguing exhibitions together! This can be the same, with a little help!

story:
What are we doing?

We are fundraising for two sets of workshops in Africa and one in New York City.

The first workshop will take place in Namibia and New York City.  The first workshop focuses on art/photography with school-aged girls, helping promote self-esteem and empowerment. These girls will learn photography skills and experiment with mixed media, ultimately creating their own "visual story". Through the use of photography and art, they will experience accomplishment, empowerment, and increased self-esteem. Pieces from this workshop will be on gallery display in New York City.

The second workshop will take place at NaDEET in Namibia. We will be teaching Environment Art Making which is the practice of creating art from materials found in the direct environment, in a way that balances environmental stewardship, community development while promoting economic viability.The culmination of the workshop will create a sustainable 3 dimensional art piece created from repurposed materials through the collaboration of several workshops of school age children who attend NaDEETs program.

Sustainable art making recognizes the connection between environmental health, human health and community health.

Why is it so important?

It is quite important to help foster creativity to promote self esteem in effort to prevent real world issues that our youth face today, especially in the developing world (as well as inner city's in America) such as AIDS/HIV, teen pregnancy, school drop outs, alcohol/drug abuse, depression and poverty. We have a responsibility to invest in the children of today to help build a better tomorrow. Sustainable art making recognizes the connection between environmental health, human health and community health

Who are we? 

We are a group of seasoned, like minded art therapists from New York City that have a vision of creating art and photography workshops around the world for underserved children to help build self esteem and empower the youth of today! 

How are we are qualified to do this?

Between the 3 of us we have several years experience working with children and adults in such settings as inner city schools, hospital schools, after school programming for at risk youth, residential treatment facilities, nursing homes, prisons, homeless shelters and public and private psychiatric hospitals in and around New York City. 

Why do art with kids? 

We believe, that giving a child the chance to be creative in a supportive environment yield many positive results such as learned basic art and photography techniques, help build self esteem and allow the playfulness of childhood thrive. 


Where is your money going?

12-20 digital cameras

Batteries/chargers 

Art supplies such as drawing materials, paint, paper, sculpture materials

Printer for photos with paper

Exhibition materials

Travel costs to Namibia (air and ground transportation)

Overhead costs

If we reach our goal, we will be able to fund the program for approximately 3 months. With more funding, we can continue longer! 

Why We Can Succeed! 

In 2009, Cheryl and her partner Christi traveled to Namibia and created a pilot program through a collaboration with NaDEET (Namib Desert Environmental Education Trust)

Using art with several groups of children over a span of 2 months, we saw first hand how powerful art can be! NaDEET reaches most of the children of Namibia despite their socio economic status. This gave us the platform to work with everyone! We also provided professional development trainings to the educators and administration as well a created a mural for the camp. 

We also learned that building alliances with already established programs like NaDEET, opens the door to beautiful collaborations that can have a lasting effect and reach many different people. For this reason, we have opened up to other organizations around the world that have welcomed our collaborative efforts but with this comes our need to be self funded (that's where you come in, see?)

It's 4 years later, we restructured and joined with The Brooklyn Arts Council as a fiscal sponsor, added new, innovative art therapists to help support and build the art curriculum, and gained invaluable field experience in our hometown. We believe it is important to give back to your own community, which is why we hope to be able to facilitate workshops in NYC and exhibit work upon our return from Namibia. 

Other ways to help! 

Low on cash? No Problem! Please help us make some noise! Retweet, repost, email, word of mouth, what ever it takes to help us spread the word about our project would be excellent! 

Please note that any donation can be made in the name of anyone you would like! Perfect for the gift giving season! The Perk with personalized card! Just say the word!

story:
The Place

My name is Justin and I have been putting up artwork around the neighborhood and greater L.A area since 2006. This project is about Glassellland and its story.  You can listen to the original recording and add to the archives through the GLASSELLLAND phone number, (206) 734-5545.  Listen to some of the other responses people have recorded.  

This isn't just about Glassell Park.  This is about Cypress Park, Eagle Rock, and Atwater Village.  This is about LA as a walkable, hackable, discoverable place beyond the freeways and movie screens.  This is contextual art.  But don't just look to me and my stuff to see what I'm talking about.  Look to the LA River, Downtown and Boyle Heights.

UPDATE (2/22):

I want to give a big Thank You to Ball-Nogues Studio for their in-kind donation to cut the letters for the new GLASSELLLAND!

You can find out more about this studio and the incredible work they do here:  

http://www.ball-nogues.com/


UPDATE (2/17):

I'm pleased to announce that I am teaming up with N.E.L.A. Clothing Company to produce the GLASSELLLAND T-Shirts.  Situated in our own neighborhood, N.E.L.A. Clothing Company features local artists who represent the unique and culturally diverse Northeast Los Angeles area. Check out some of their other designs created by Chaz Bojórquez and Dave Tourjé here:

http://www.nelaclothingcompany.com/


UPDATE (2/12):

This campaign has gotten a lot of love from the press.  I greatly appreciate it, but it is you, the campaign supporter, that ultimately makes this happen!  Thank you! 

Take a look at the links below:

The Eastsider LA

Curbed LA

LA Weekly

UPDATE (2/10):


A More Recent History

The installation was put up last year on a hill below the Forest Lawn Cemetery.  Some of you caught sight of it, but it was quickly taken down.  If big government doesn't work, someone should tell CalTrans.

 

The sign was redesigned, twice as big, and relocated to a hill overlooking the local park: Glassell Park. It was visible from the baseball diamond, the swimming pool, and the 2 freeway.  

Although great advertisement for the vacant property, the sign was not authorized by the owner and was eventually removed.

Good News!

The installation will go back up!  I have located property close to the prior location with owners who have authorized placement of the sign.  Should this campaign fall short, I have contacted locals who are willing to help cobble something together that looks like letters and put it on a hill in a legible fashion.  I encourage you to donate to the effort, however. (Especially that couple that was making out behind the "D."  You know who you are. This sign is for you!) The more investment, the better the sign.

Basic funding goes towards the redesign, fabrication, and installation of the project. Funding beyond the goal will go towards a comprehensive support structure, long-term maintenance, and solar-powered lighting. 

Even further funding will go towards new public projects.  Bigger and badder projects. Here are a few past projects you may have seen around town:

      

     

                                 


      

 

Perks:

    

     (You can Baldessari your life, too: http://www.baldessariyourlife.com)


   SREET SIGNS: Homemade, hand painted, and fresh out of the oven.

    (These signs come with wall hanging hardware on the back.  Please add $5 if you would like mounting hardware to mount the sign to a perforated square steel pole.)
story_txt:
The PlaceMy name is Justin and I have been putting up artwork around the neighborhood and greater L.A area since 2006. This project is about Glassellland and its story.  You can listen to the original recording and add to the archives through the GLASSELLLAND phone number, (206) 734-5545.  Listen to some of the other responses people have recorded.  This isn't just about Glassell Park.  This is about Cypress Park, Eagle Rock, and Atwater Village.  This is about LA as a walkable, hackable, discoverable place beyond the freeways and movie screens.  This is contextual art.  But don't just look to me and my stuff to see what I'm talking about.  Look to the LA River, Downtown and Boyle Heights.UPDATE (2/22):I want to give a big Thank You to Ball-Nogues Studio for their in-kind donation to cut the letters for the new GLASSELLLAND!You can find out more about this studio and the incredible work they do here:  http://www.ball-nogues.com/UPDATE (2/17):I'm pleased to announce that I am teaming up with N.E.L.A. Clothing Company to produce the GLASSELLLAND T-Shirts.  Situated in our own neighborhood, N.E.L.A. Clothing Company features local artists who represent the unique and culturally diverse Northeast Los Angeles area. Check out some of their other designs created by Chaz Bojórquez and Dave Tourjé here:http://www.nelaclothingcompany.com/
UPDATE (2/12):
This campaign has gotten a lot of love from the press.  I greatly appreciate it, but it is you, the campaign supporter, that ultimately makes this happen!  Thank you! 
Take a look at the links below:
The Eastsider LA
Curbed LA
LA Weekly

UPDATE (2/10):A More Recent HistoryThe installation was put up last year on a hill below the Forest Lawn Cemetery.  Some of you caught sight of it, but it was quickly taken down.  If big government doesn't work, someone should tell CalTrans. The sign was redesigned, twice as big, and relocated to a hill overlooking the local park: Glassell Park. It was visible from the baseball diamond, the swimming pool, and the 2 freeway.  Although great advertisement for the vacant property, the sign was not authorized by the owner and was eventually removed.Good News!The installation will go back up!  I have located property close to the prior location with owners who have authorized placement of the sign.  Should this campaign fall short, I have contacted locals who are willing to help cobble something together that looks like letters and put it on a hill in a legible fashion.  I encourage you to donate to the effort, however. (Especially that couple that was making out behind the "D."  You know who you are. This sign is for you!) The more investment, the better the sign.Basic funding goes towards the redesign, fabrication, and installation of the project. Funding beyond the goal will go towards a comprehensive support structure, long-term maintenance, and solar-powered lighting. Even further funding will go towards new public projects.  Bigger and badder projects. Here are a few past projects you may have seen around town:                                                   Perks:         (You can Baldessari your life, too: http://www.baldessariyourlife.com)   SREET SIGNS: Homemade, hand painted, and fresh out of the oven.    (These signs come with wall hanging hardware on the back.  Please add $5 if you would like mounting hardware to mount the sign to a perforated square steel pole.)

story:
Artist, Adel deValcourt

  • Adel deValcourt is a Visual Artist, Licensed Art Teacher and ULL Alumni. 
  • 20+ yrs Working and 15+ yrs Teaching Ceramics.
  • I am proud of my home town, Lafayette Louisiana, and plan to give back, as we Reshape and Revitalize the Hub City.
  • Resume/CV : HandStarDesigns.
  • The Clay Studio: HandStarClayStudio.
  • Etsy Store: Online Shopping.
  • We need $30,000 to jumpstart our Clay Studio and presence in Lafayette, Louisiana. To accommodate more students, Hand Star Clay Studio needs a conducive, safe location, more equipment, studio furniture and the ability to market our services in and around south Louisiana. The more wheels we have the more students we can accommodate!!

What We Currently Have:

  • Electric kiln, Slab roller,  Four pottery wheels, 10 x 10 EZ-Up tent and weights, bats, scale, glaze materials, stamps, brushes, community tools, a growing library and a wide variety of other educational resources.  
  • If we reach or go beyond our goal the funds will be spent on: 

What We Need:

Equipment:  (14,000$) Electric Kiln, Raku Kiln, 6 pottery wheels, clay extruder, bench grinder, banding wheels.  We would love to eventually get a truck for easier loading and unloading, for shows and traveling classes.

                    

Renovations:  (6,000$) Ventilation Upgrade, Track Lighting, Painting, Studio sinks, Electricity Upgrade. HVAC and OSHA Standards are very important to us, as well as our students comfort and ease.

Furniture: (4,000$) Two large work tables covered with canvas, shelving units, stools, baker-racks, pedestals and moveable walls for showroom.

Marketing:  (6,000$) Participation in Local Markets, Photography Lighting, Paper and Radio Ads, Business Cards and Promotional gear, Website and social media upkeep.  We would love to get an Ipad for business use.

*Approximately 10% of our total raised will go back into Indiegogo and to cover Credit Card Fees.

If we Do Not reach our goal the funds will be spent on: 

  • 1st Location/Renovations
  • 2nd Furniture and Equipment
  • 3rd Marketing. 

What you get with our Perks:

  • Hand Print Stickers from our Logo in Red or Black.  Special Thanks to Julie Ruth of Loka Creative!
  • Francis Pavy Screen-print, Denise McCluggage Photograph, Henna Tattoo sessions, Private Lessons and 4 nights in Santa Fe View Room!!   I will even Cook a dinner at Your House and Supply you with a set of 4 of my Handmade Dishes !!

Hand and Paw Print Medallion's

Variety of Mugs

 Tshirt with our Logo

Variety of Bamboo Soapdishes

Polka Dot Plate

Henna Tattoos

Raku Vase

Black and White Plate

Denise McCluggage:  Ferrari Transporter 

 Francis X Pavy:  'Dancers' Screenprint

The Impact

  • The potential of Hand Star Clay Studio is not only to engage Lafayette's community, but also to bring talented national and international artists to our town for special workshops and events.
  • My commitment to the arts and the arts community has and will remain lasting.  
  • I want to help shape Lafayette into an eclectic place where tourists and collectors come to meet, shop and experience a great time!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Pass around our Fundraiser Postcard to friends, family and those that support the local arts.  Whoojoo Stained Glass Gallery will have a stack.
  • Contact us about upcoming classes and workshops!!
  • Join us for our Finale Party. June 14th at Whoojoo Glass, Downtown Lafayette from 6-9pm.  
  • More One-of-a-Kinds can be purchased:  https://www.etsy.com/shop/HandStarDesigns

story:
Hi my name is Malcolm Tait I am an artist based on the East Coast county of Lincolnshire in the UK near the town of Skegness.

This project supports three aims, the primary object is to raise money for Skegness Lifeboat, a remarkable institution, the second to raise funding to enable future projects to be developed at the Embassy Theatre Gallery Space and thirdly to help me develop my art practice and fund materials and running costs for the project. As well as money from the donations going to the beneficiaries the main source of fundraising will be the auctioning by sealed bids of the work through the project exhibition at the Embassy Theatre Gallery Space. The Exhibition runs from the 14th of February till the 6th of April.

Five of the seven images can be viewed on the Gallery page, the two remaining images will be available to view before the Exhibition opens on the 14th February, keep watching the gallery page. 

This project is important to me for three simple reasons, firstly my love of art and drawing, secondly the act of giving something back and thirdly I like the community I live in.

There are five donation options but because there are three beneficiaries I have included a breakdown where the money from each donation goes.

Thanks for taking the time to look at this, if you can donate that is brilliant, thank you, but if you can’t and still like the project please tell other about it. Thank you for your support.
